target: The authors introduce a general solution named ALT, a method that works alongside most existing GNNs to handle graphs with either low or high homophily effectively. ALT decomposes a graph into two components, extracts complementary signals, and merges them adaptively for node classification.
prediction: The authors propose Geometric Graph Representation Learning (G2R), which learns node representations in an unsupervised manner by maximizing rate reduction. Under this approach, nodes in different groups are mapped into compact, diversely distributed subspaces.

log.reference: The authors propose Geometric Graph Representation Learning (G2R), which learns node representations in an unsupervised manner by maximizing rate reduction. Under this approach, nodes in different groups are mapped into compact, diversely distributed subspaces.

The authors present the idea that Deep Graph Learning (DGL) enables an end-to-end methodology for learning informative representations of graphs, eliminating the need for complicated feature engineering.

The authors propose Cross-View Graph Diffusion (CGD), a general and parameter-free method with convergence guarantee for multi-view data clustering. It is the first approach to use diffusion process for multi-view clustering.

A novel framework called Active Semi-supervised Graph Neural Network (ASGN) is presented. This framework incorporates both labeled and unlabeled molecules, employing a teacher-student paradigm, with the teacher model learning a general representation that jointly exploits information from molecular structure and molecular distribution, and the student model targeting property prediction to deal with learning loss conflict.

The authors propose a new method, the graph clustered federated learning (GCFL) framework. This framework dynamically finds clusters of local systems based on the gradients of graph neural networks (GNNs), with the aim of reducing the structure and feature heterogeneity among graphs owned by the local systems.

target: The authors conduct a systematic evaluation of toxicity in chatbot language models, specifically in ChatGPT. They examine the impact of assigning a persona to the model on the toxicity in its generations.
prediction: The authors developed a method to detect absurd conversations in intelligent assistant logs by identifying user feedback utterances that showcase favorable or unfavorable attitudes towards intelligent assistant responses. They propose training a conversation classifier that recognizes conversations as either absurd or not.

log.reference: The authors developed a method to detect absurd conversations in intelligent assistant logs by identifying user feedback utterances that showcase favorable or unfavorable attitudes towards intelligent assistant responses. They propose training a conversation classifier that recognizes conversations as either absurd or not.

Under the AMITIES project, the developers aim to create a dialogue management system capable of engaging the user in human-like conversation within the specific domain of telephone-based customer service.

The authors propose a voice-based conversational agent called 'Shing' that proactively initiates and repairs the conversation, uses empathetical communication skills to alert customers on suspected online-payment frauds, collects crucial information for scrutinizing the possible fraud, and persuades customers to terminate the transaction once the fraud is confirmed.

The authors propose an automatic news chat-bot that organizes news articles into topical chatrooms, integrates automatically generated questions into conversations, and uses a novel method to avoid repetitive question suggestions.

This paper scrutinizes on how well current conversational QA systems generalize to real-world human-machine conversation scenarios and it also assesses the need for developing more representative benchmarks.

target: The team PAI proposes a universal Named Entity Recognition (NER) system that integrates external entity information to improve performance. This system retrieves entities with properties from a knowledge base for a given text, then concatenates this entity information with the input sentence and feeds it into Transformer-based models.
prediction: The study proposes the use of Named Entity Recognition (NER), a text mining method, to effectively extract useful information from volumes of free-text research literature on Alzheimer's Dementia (AD).

log.reference: The study proposes the use of Named Entity Recognition (NER), a text mining method, to effectively extract useful information from volumes of free-text research literature on Alzheimer's Dementia (AD).

The authors propose a novel layered method for nested named entity recognition that explicitly excludes the influence of the best path. This method also leverages the recognition of innermost entities first which they argue gives better performance.
The authors propose a quick adjustment to an existing NER system to further recognize new entity types by using previously labeled data and entity lexicons of the newly defined entity types.

The paper proposes CHEMNER, an ontology-guided, distantly-supervised method for fine-grained chemistry NER. The method leverage chemistry type ontology structure to generate distant labels with flexible KB-matching and ontology-guided multi-type disambiguation.

The authors propose a general-purpose, modular neural semantic parsing framework based on token-level fine-grained query understanding. The proposed framework consists three modules: a named entity recognizer (NER), a neural entity linker (NEL), and a neural semantic parser (NSP).

target: We propose a Hierarchical Attention model for HKG Embedding (HAHE), including global-level and local-level attention. The global-level attention models the graphical structure of HKG using hypergraph dual-attention layers, while the local-level attention learns the sequential structure inside H-Facts via heterogeneous self-attention layers.
prediction: The authors propose an Interactive Attention Transfer Network (IATN) for cross-domain sentiment classification that includes an interactive attention transfer mechanism, to better transfer sentiment across domains by incorporating both sentence and aspect information.

log.reference: The authors propose an Interactive Attention Transfer Network (IATN) for cross-domain sentiment classification that includes an interactive attention transfer mechanism, to better transfer sentiment across domains by incorporating both sentence and aspect information.

The authors propose a CNN-based network for NER known as the Gated Relation Network (GRN), which effectively captures long-term context. The GRN utilises CNNs for local context feature exploration, then models word relations and uses them as gates to fuse local features into global ones.

The authors propose a dual-interactive graph attention networks (DIGAT) that has two channels: the news-graph and the user-graph channel. In the news-graph channel, the semantics of single candidate news is enriched by incorporating semantically relevant news information via a semantic-augmented graph (SAG). In the user-graph channel, multi-level user interests are represented with a news-topic graph. The authors design a dual-graph interaction process for effective feature interaction between the two graphs.

To improve the quality of candidate sets and reduce noise in the Entity Linking task, the authors propose a new multi-strategy-based candidate generation method and a Sequential Graph Attention Network (SeqGAT) which combines the benefits of graph and sequence methods.

The authors propose an extension to neural network language models that connect the use of external memory in neural networks with cache models used in count-based language models. The mechanism used is a simplified version of memory augmented networks that can scale to large memory sizes.

target: The authors created four language models for Ancient Greek, varying by model type (RoBERTa and T5) and language composition (monolingual Ancient Greek or multilingual including Latin and English), providing a wide-ranging study on their applicability for Classical philology tasks.
prediction: The authors propose the application of a BERT language model to the study of Ancient Greek. This model is intended to uncover statistical properties that can provide insights into the authorship and context of Pseudo-Plutarch texts.

log.reference: The authors propose the application of a BERT language model to the study of Ancient Greek. This model is intended to uncover statistical properties that can provide insights into the authorship and context of Pseudo-Plutarch texts.

The authors propose to enhance BERT-based models for low-resource language varieties through zero-shot transfer learning. They retrain the lexical layers of these models using data from two target languages and independently fine-tune the Transformer layers on a POS-tagging task in the model's source language.
The authors propose 'Bernice', a multilingual RoBERTa language model, trained from scratch on 2.5 billion tweets using a custom tweet-focused tokenizer.
The authors propose to train a robustly optimized BERT approach, RoBERTa, on Dutch language, creating a Dutch language model named RobBERT.

The authors propose a simple yet effective lexical-level masking strategy, observing that temporal generalization is closely related to lexical semantic change, a key characteristic of natural languages.

target: In this paper, the authors propose a method of re-parameterizing and fine-tuning PLMs by discovering intrinsic task-specific subspaces. This is done by exploiting the dynamics of the fine-tuning process for a given task and learning the parameter optimization trajectory.
prediction: The paper attempts to prove an analytical connection between the seemingly different tasks of density estimation and sensory integration.

log.reference: The paper attempts to prove an analytical connection between the seemingly different tasks of density estimation and sensory integration.

In this paper, we propose a novel binary classification training framework, SphereFace2, that bypasses the softmax normalization along with the corresponding closed-set assumption, effectively bridging the gap between training and evaluation. This new framework seeks to improve the representations individually for each binary classification task.

The authors propose HYDRA (Hypergradient Data Relevance Analysis), a technique that interprets the predictions made by DNNs as effects of their training data and assesses the contribution of training data toward test data points throughout the training trajectory.

The authors propose a method of using efficient truncated randomized search in the scalar reward function to train structured prediction energy networks (SPENs), which avoids the traditional need for labeled training data.

The authors propose the use of  the state-of-the-art attribution-based confidence (ABC) metric to detect deepfake videos, using only the trained model and without requiring access to training or validation data.

target: The authors present a new task setting for attribute mining on e-commerce products, which extracts open-world attributes with minimal human intervention using a seed attribute set. They also propose a method, Amacer, designed specifically to handle this limited supervision.
prediction: The authors propose an open-world approach to attribute mining that can extract novel attributes and their values from e-commerce product descriptions, using weak supervision where users provide a few examples of known attributes.

log.reference: The authors propose an open-world approach to attribute mining that can extract novel attributes and their values from e-commerce product descriptions, using weak supervision where users provide a few examples of known attributes.

The authors propose the Hierarchical burnout Prediction based on Activity Logs (HiPAL), a deep learning framework for predicting physician burnout using digital records of physician work activities available in Electronic Health Records. The HiPAL model uniquely uses a pre-trained time-dependent activity embedding mechanism tailored for activity logs and a hierarchical predictive model to capture evolving burnout risk over short-term and long-term levels.

The paper introduces a computational model with a truth-conditional architecture. It runs small learned programs on the input time series, identifies the programs/patterns which hold true for the given input, and then conditions on only these valid programs to generate the text description, rather than using the entire input time series.

This paper proposes a novel framework that uses a Demographic feature restricted Hidden Markov Model (DfrHMM) to capture the trajectory of latent states representing a patient's condition, inferred from their behavioral data while considering their demographic similarities and differences to other patients.
The authors propose TimeSHAP, a model-agnostic recurrent explainer that builds upon KernelSHAP and extends it to the sequential domain to compute feature-, timestep-, and cell-level attributions.

target: The paper proposes a method for building personalized open-domain dialogue systems that solve the WWH problem using tools such as weighted dataset blending, negative persona information augmentation, and personalized conversation datasets.
prediction: The paper proposes a shift in perspective that places spoken dialog in the context of the larger collaborative challenge of managing parallel, coordinated actions in the open world.

log.reference: The paper proposes a shift in perspective that places spoken dialog in the context of the larger collaborative challenge of managing parallel, coordinated actions in the open world.

This study introduces the idea of evaluating the performance of a dialogue system by computing the distribution-wise distance between its generated conversations and real-world conversations, using two proposed metrics: FBD and PRD.

The authors suggest that fictional dialogs can be employed to study whether adaptation in linguistic style is a reflex embedded in the language-generation process, given that authors, though they write the conversations, don't receive the social benefits.

The paper introduces three important aspects for real-world dialog systems: language variety, speech characteristics, and noise perturbation. A model-agnostic toolkit, LAUG, is proposed to approximate natural language perturbations and test robustness of task-oriented dialog systems.
The authors propose a machine learning approach to learn rules from a dialogue corpus for identifying situations where the speech recognizer is performing poorly.

target: The authors propose the RST Continuity Corpus (RST-CC), a corpus of discourse relations annotated for continuity dimensions using operationalised versions of Givón’s (1993) continuity dimensions.
prediction: The paper introduces Rhetorical Structure Theory, a new text structure theory where each region of text has a central nuclear part and several satellites related to it.

log.reference: The paper introduces Rhetorical Structure Theory, a new text structure theory where each region of text has a central nuclear part and several satellites related to it.

The paper proposes the use of indexed constraints to represent a syntax tree or standard semantic representation in task-oriented dialogue systems to allow for interpretation rules that incorporate structural and contextual constraints.

In this paper, the authors apply kernel methods on syntactic/semantic structures for the accurate classification of Jeopardy! definition questions, aiming to improve the existing word-language model-based classifiers.
The authors propose an underspecified version of SDRT (USDRT), which can express ambiguities within discourse structures and anaphora.

The authors propose RUSS (Rapid Universal Support Service), a tool that utilises a two-part model comprising a BERT-LSTM with pointers and a grounding model, to parse instructions to ThingTalk, a domain-specific language designed by the authors for grounding natural language on the web.

target: The paper introduces a new quantum machine learning model, Variational Quantum Network Embedding (VQNE), that uses quantum walk to extract structure information from two aligning networks and also adopts a quantum embedding ansatz for learning each node's latent representation, avoiding high quantum gate cost and the need for classic-quantum communication.
prediction: This paper presents the first study of large-scale experiments for predicting next career moves using two sources of predictive signals: profile context matching and career path mining. The authors propose a contextual LSTM model named NEMO for capturing these signals by jointly learning latent representations for different types of entities.

log.reference: This paper presents the first study of large-scale experiments for predicting next career moves using two sources of predictive signals: profile context matching and career path mining. The authors propose a contextual LSTM model named NEMO for capturing these signals by jointly learning latent representations for different types of entities.

The paper proposes a novel quantum graph learning model that characterizes structural information using quantum parallelism to improve computing efficiency. A multi-head quantum attention mechanism is used to include semantic similarity information of nodes into the model.

The study presents a novel approach named Hierarchical Intention Embedding Network (HIEN), which integrates attribute dependencies through bottom-up tree aggregation in the constructed attribute graph, and simultaneously captures user and item intents for different item attributes with a hierarchically attentive mechanism.

The authors propose a novel Multi-Granularity Semantic Aware Graph model (MGSAG) that incorporates both fine-grained and coarse-grained semantic features without considering distance limitations. This done by exploring semantic dependencies between clauses and keywords extracted from the document, and establishing a clause graph to model coarse-grained semantic relations.

The paper proposes a Multi-view Intent Disentangle Graph Networks (MIDGN) model that captures both the global view of user intents—considering a user's multiple intents across different bundles, and the local view of their intents—consistently tied to items within each bundle.

target: The authors propose GCBA, the first backdoor attack specifically designed for graph contrastive learning. This includes three types of attacks: poisoning, crafting, and natural backdoor, each targetting a different stage of the GCL pipeline.
prediction: The authors propose a new Model Poisoning Attack based on Fake clients (MPAF), where the attacker injects fake clients into a federated learning system and sends carefully crafted fake local model updates to the cloud server during training, such that the learned global model has low accuracy for many indiscriminate test inputs.

log.reference: The authors propose a new Model Poisoning Attack based on Fake clients (MPAF), where the attacker injects fake clients into a federated learning system and sends carefully crafted fake local model updates to the cloud server during training, such that the learned global model has low accuracy for many indiscriminate test inputs.
The authors develop a new data poisoning attack that allows an adversary to control model predictions whenever a desired trigger phrase is present in the input.

The study aims to design new attack methods targeting deep learning-based recommender models in federated learning scenarios. The authors propose attacks that generate poisoned gradients for manipulated malicious users to upload based on two strategies: random approximation and hard user mining.

The authors discover that backdoor neurons are exposed by their pre-activation distributions, where populations from benign data and poisoned data show significantly different moments, a property that is attack invariant.

This paper focuses on data poisoning attacks against crowdsourcing systems that use the Dawid-Skene model, and proposes an intelligent attack mechanism which maximizes the attack utility while disguising the attacking behaviors.

target: The authors propose a novel method for generating general foreground-background segmentation models from simple textual descriptions, eliminating the need for segmentation labels. This method uses pre-trained latent diffusion models to create weak segmentation masks for concepts and objects, which are then used to fine-tune the diffusion model on an inpainting task.
prediction: This paper proposes a methodology to train a local model that effectively solves the domain shift problem. It focuses on building footprint segmentation over a single large satellite imagery scene using very few labels.

log.reference: This paper proposes a methodology to train a local model that effectively solves the domain shift problem. It focuses on building footprint segmentation over a single large satellite imagery scene using very few labels.

This study introduces T-PARINET, an access method for efficiently retrieving the trajectories of objects moving within networks. T-PARINET is based on PARINET, an efficient index for historical trajectory data, which is built on graph partitioning and a set of composite B+-tree local indexes.

The authors propose a new approach called 'sketch tokens', which are learned using supervised mid-level information in the form of hand drawn contours in images, and employ a random forest classifier for efficient detection in novel images.

The authors propose that context plays a vital role in dense scene labeling in small images, in addition to the appearance of an object. Their algorithm uses both the segment's appearance and contextual information to categorize each segment.

POIsam, a visualization system, is presented that can maintain representativeness, visibility constraint, zooming consistency, and panning consistency for the efficient selection of representative objects from a user's current region of interest, discarding the common assumption of pre-defined cells.

target: The authors propose the Tiny Updater - a novel training methodology that allows a fraction (10%~20%) of the parameters to update neural network-based software, building upon previous model compression research.
prediction: The authors propose two new pruning methods that aim to integrate the pre- and post-pruning approaches to achieve both accuracy and efficiency.

log.reference: The authors propose two new pruning methods that aim to integrate the pre- and post-pruning approaches to achieve both accuracy and efficiency.

The authors propose Gradient-based Intra-attention pruning (GRAIN), which examines fine intra-attention structures and allows for different head sizes. The authors also introduce structure regularization for generating more regular structures and a gradient separation strategy to integrate KD into the pruning process without interference.

This paper indicates a performance discrepancy in magnitude-based pruning between standard supervised learning and the zero-shot setting, and suggests two weight regularizers to maximize alignment between pruned and unpruned networks. This could reduce distortion in the alignment of pruned cross-lingual models and improve performance in both non zero-shot and zero-shot settings.

The authors explore layer freezing and data sieving as two techniques to effectively and efficiently reduce sparse training costs while preserving accuracy. Layer freezing is a technique used in dense model training and fine-tuning but has not been adopted in sparse training. Data sieving is a proposed method for dataset-efficient training, reducing costs by using only a partial dataset throughout the entire training process.

The authors propose a novel pruning method called Fairness-aware GRAdient Pruning mEthod (FairGRAPE) that minimizes the disproportionate impacts of pruning on different sub-groups by calculating the per-group importance of each model weight and selecting a subset of weights that maintain the relative between-group total importance in pruning.

target: The authors propose the GRAND-SLAMIN framework for learning GAMs with interactions under sparsity and additional structural constraints. This tool offers flexibility, scalability, and accuracy across differentiable loss functions and is implemented using first-order gradient-based optimization and sparse backpropagation.
prediction: This paper introduced a new method that employs stagewise linear combinations of collaborative filtering algorithms, using non-constant combination coefficients based on kernel smoothing.

log.reference: This paper introduced a new method that employs stagewise linear combinations of collaborative filtering algorithms, using non-constant combination coefficients based on kernel smoothing.

The study presents a new approach to learn DAGs and factor models within the same framework, using Bayesian hierarchies based on spike and slab priors for promoting sparsity, heavy-tailed priors for identifiability, and predictive densities for model comparison.

The authors propose a novel formulation of fully corrective boosting for multi-class classification problems that incorporates the idea of sharing features through the introduction of mixed-norm regularization promoting group sparsity.

The authors introduce a new class of models for high-dimensional nonparametric regression and classification called sparse additive models (SpAM), which combine ideas from sparse linear modeling and additive nonparametric regression.
The authors propose a latent variable model for PGA that provides a probabilistic framework for factor analysis on manifolds.

target: This paper introduces PaintSeg, a novel unsupervised method for segmenting objects without any training. It uses an adversarial masked contrastive painting (AMCP) process which creates a contrast between the original image and a painted image.
prediction: The authors propose a novel algorithm that generates superpixels which adhere to a grid, forming a regular superpixel lattice, without losing the position or relationship with neighboring superpixels.

log.reference: The authors propose a novel algorithm that generates superpixels which adhere to a grid, forming a regular superpixel lattice, without losing the position or relationship with neighboring superpixels.

The authors propose a new algorithmic way to generate clusters from a graph without exponentially increasing the graph's size during triangulation. They also introduce the use of superpixels for the nodes of the graph for statistical region labeling, which is a more natural representation of an image than the pixel grid.

The authors propose a new metric that does not require segmentation labels and measures the stability of predictions from segmentation networks across a sequence of images, thereby accounting for temporal consistency.

The authors propose a novel generative model based on a linked hierarchy of probabilistic segmentations, along with a new image similarity kernel, which together generate a rich backdrop for image recognition, segmentation, and registration tasks.

The paper introduces a new framework that uses probabilistic multinets to integrate region-based and contour-based image segmentation constraints, representing the relationships between image pixels, region labels, and object contours via a graphical model.

target: A new algorithm is proposed for evaluating conjunctive queries with both short and long comparisons, and an acyclic condition is identified under which linear time can be achieved.
prediction: The authors propose the MiniCon algorithm, a novel algorithm for finding the maximally-contained rewriting of a conjunctive query using a set of conjunctive views.

log.reference: The authors propose the MiniCon algorithm, a novel algorithm for finding the maximally-contained rewriting of a conjunctive query using a set of conjunctive views.

This paper investigates and provides evidence that the inefficiency of bottom-up knowledge compilation is due to the bottom-up paradigm itself, even for CNF formulas which have very small circuit representations in structured decomposable negation normal forms (str-DNNF), one of the most general languages.

The study proposes the Extended Disjunctive Normal Form (EDNF), a basis for processing logic queries in loosely coupled environments, which extends the relational algebra expressions to include recursion. The EDNF is compatible with an existing DBMS and supports optimization.

The authors propose MiniCon, a novel algorithm designed for finding the maximally-contained rewriting of a conjunctive query using a set of conjunctive views, addressing both performance and scalability concerns.

A model theoretic approach to probabilistic lifted inference is proposed. This approach compiles a first-order probabilistic theory into a first-order deterministic decomposable negation normal form (d-DNNF) circuit.

target: The paper proposes that detectors be designed to reach tradeoffs between energy and performance. The authors propose a balanced detector driven by energy using discovered low-energy components named FemtoDet. A new instance boundary enhancement (IBE) module and a recursive warm-restart (RecWR) for optimizing training strategy are introduced.
prediction: The authors propose an extended KinectFusion pipeline that incorporates per-pixel semantic labels from the input frames, storing per-voxel information on the types of objects likely to appear in each spatial location, thus creating a SemanticFusion loop.

log.reference: The authors propose an extended KinectFusion pipeline that incorporates per-pixel semantic labels from the input frames, storing per-voxel information on the types of objects likely to appear in each spatial location, thus creating a SemanticFusion loop.
The study explores how improvement can be achieved in the modeling of the output distribution using an autoregressive prediction head for 3D bounding box prediction.

The authors propose a camera source identification methodology based on the extraction of Discrete Cosine Transform Residual features and subsequent ensemble classification using a Random Forest model enhanced with AdaBoost.

We propose a Label-Guided auxiliary training method for 3D object detection (LG3D), which serves as an auxiliary network to enhance the feature learning of existing 3D object detectors, utilizing two novel modules: a Label-Annotation-Inducer and a Label-Knowledge-Mapper.

The authors propose MonteBoxFinder, a method that fits cuboids to noisy input scenes and features a discrete optimization algorithm for efficiently filtering good boxes from the noisy ones. Key to this is the usage of a stochastic algorithm inspired by Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS).

target: The authors argue based on information-theoretic reasoning that perfect modality alignment can actually be sub-optimal for downstream tasks. They propose that the key to better performance lies in constructing meaningful latent modality structures.
prediction: The paper introduces LOUPE, a fine-grained semantically aligned vision-language pre-training framework that learns fine-grained semantic alignment from the novel perspective of game-theoretic interactions.

log.reference: The paper introduces LOUPE, a fine-grained semantically aligned vision-language pre-training framework that learns fine-grained semantic alignment from the novel perspective of game-theoretic interactions.

The paper introduces a novel Positive-nEgative frame mask for Music Representation based on the contrastive learning framework (PEMR). PEMR incorporates a Positive-Negative Mask Generation module, which uses transformer blocks to generate frame masks on Log-Mel spectrogram.

The authors propose a method to identify abnormal findings from radiology reports rather than produce complete reports. They suggest a new approach that groups abnormalities using unsupervised clustering and minimal rules for targeting abnormalities only.

The authors propose novel self-supervised graph masking pre-training strategies that do not require supervision signals and do not require changing the architecture of the underlying pre-trained encoder-decoder model.

To improve the clinical correctness of generated reports from an imbalanced dataset, a novel reinforcement learning method with a reconstructor is proposed. In addition, a new data augmentation strategy for reinforcement learning is introduced for training on infrequent findings. A Two-Stage Medical Report Generator (TS-MRGen) is implemented for controllable report generation.

target: The authors argue that the modality gap between speech and text data in E2E ST doesn't vastly impact final performance and that the capacity gap plays a crucial part to sub-optimal results. They propose focusing on regularization rather than modality adaption.
prediction: The authors propose a method to identify abnormal findings from radiology reports rather than produce complete reports. They suggest a new approach that groups abnormalities using unsupervised clustering and minimal rules for targeting abnormalities only.

log.reference: The authors propose a method to identify abnormal findings from radiology reports rather than produce complete reports. They suggest a new approach that groups abnormalities using unsupervised clustering and minimal rules for targeting abnormalities only.

A new concept for language-conditioned RL is proposed, which is the Language-Goal-Behavior (LGB) architecture. LGB separates skill learning and language grounding through an intermediate semantic representation of the world. The authors present DECSTR, a specific implementation of LGB.

The authors aim to explore whether language models' learned conceptual structure can reflect the non-linguistic world's conceptual structure. They propose a method of teaching language models to map an entire conceptual domain, such as direction or colour, onto a grounded world representation using a small number of examples.

The authors propose a framework that leverages the structure information in CXR reports to generate improved reports. This is achieved by modeling the relationship between 'Findings' and 'Impression' sections, and designing a cooperative multi-agent system to capture the imbalanced distribution between abnormality and normality.

To address these challenges the authors propose the AISLe model, which employs adversarial learning and importance sampling for precision and coverage, and a multimodal multiscale attention block for subword alignment without explicit alignment between language and acoustic cues.

target: The authors proposed a novel adversarial training framework for spatiotemporal traffic forecasting tasks. The framework incorporates a reinforcement learning-based method for optimal node selection, alongside a self-knowledge distillation regularization module to address issues caused by changing adversarial nodes during training.
prediction: The authors proposed a practical adversarial spatiotemporal attack framework to investigate the vulnerability of spatiotemporal traffic forecasting models. Specifically, this involves an iterative gradient-guided node saliency method to identify victim nodes and a spatiotemporal gradient descent-based scheme to generate adversarial traffic states under a perturbation constraint.

log.reference: The authors proposed a practical adversarial spatiotemporal attack framework to investigate the vulnerability of spatiotemporal traffic forecasting models. Specifically, this involves an iterative gradient-guided node saliency method to identify victim nodes and a spatiotemporal gradient descent-based scheme to generate adversarial traffic states under a perturbation constraint.
The paper introduces a novel method for jointly training an energy-based model and a flow-based model with iterative updates based on a shared adversarial value function.

The authors propose a principled approach to handling mode collapse called 'packing'. This idea involves modifying the discriminator to make decisions based on multiple samples from the same class, either real or artificially generated.

The paper proposes the 'divergence triangle' as a framework for joint training of a generator model, energy-based model and inference model, integrating variational learning, adversarial learning, wake-sleep algorithm, and contrastive divergence.

The authors propose a novel bilevel optimization formulation that considers both the fusion and detection tasks. This is unrolled into a target-aware Dual Adversarial Learning (TarDAL) network for fusion, which leverages both commonalities and differences between modalities.

target: To systematically study the robustness of Table QA models, the authors propose a benchmark called RobuT. It includes human-annotated adversarial perturbations in terms of table header, table content, and question, building upon existing Table QA datasets like WTQ, WikiSQL-Weak, and SQA.
prediction: The authors propose a new approach of evaluating robustness in Chinese question matching models by using natural text with a variety of linguistic perturbations, and create a dataset for this purpose, called 'DuQM'.

log.reference: The authors propose a new approach of evaluating robustness in Chinese question matching models by using natural text with a variety of linguistic perturbations, and create a dataset for this purpose, called 'DuQM'.

The authors offer new data resources on various spatial language processing tasks. The first dataset is synthesized for transfer learning on spatial question answering (SQA) and spatial role labeling (SpRL), including a larger variety of spatial relation types and spatial expressions.

The authors propose a large-scale Geometric Question Answering dataset (GeoQA), with 5,010 geometric problems and their corresponding annotated programs. They also introduce a Neural Geometric Solver (NGS) that addresses geometric problems by parsing multimodal information and generating interpretable programs.

The authors propose MULTIHIERTT, a large-scale benchmark with QA pairs over Multi Hierarchical Tabular and Textual data, obtained from financial reports, featuring (among other things) multiple tables and longer unstructured texts per document, hierarchical tables, and complex reasoning processes. Additionally, they introduce a novel QA model, MT2Net, that first identifies relevant supporting facts from both tables and text and then performs symbolic reasoning over these facts.

The authors propose Unified-QG, a model that uses lifelong learning techniques to continually learn QG tasks across different datasets and formats. They use a format-convert encoding to transform different kinds of QG formats into a unified representation.

target: The authors propose Concept2Box, a novel approach that embeds both the ontological view and the instance view of a knowledge graph using dual geometric representations; concepts are modeled using box embeddings, capturing their hierarchy and relationships like overlap and disjoint, and entities are modeled as vectors.
prediction: The authors propose a new neural language model that includes an interpretable neuro-symbolic knowledge base (KB) in the form of a 'fact memory'. Each element of the fact memory is formed from a triple of vectors representing a KB entity or relation.

log.reference: The authors propose a new neural language model that includes an interpretable neuro-symbolic knowledge base (KB) in the form of a 'fact memory'. Each element of the fact memory is formed from a triple of vectors representing a KB entity or relation.
This paper introduces Word2Box, which uses box embeddings to capture set-theoretic semantics of words. A fuzzy-set interpretation of box embeddings is provided.

The authors propose a new three-layered representation of SciKGs. This model includes concept nodes, attribute nodes, and their links, nodes representing fact tuples and condition tuples, and statement nodes that are traceable to their original paper and authors.

The authors propose an embedding-based method called NewLook to address the limitations of previous methods. NewLook supports four types of logical operations and can answer queries with multiple variable nodes.

The authors propose TranSparse, a novel approach to address the heterogeneity and imbalance of knowledge graphs. This is achieved by replacing transfer matrices with adaptive sparse matrices, where their sparsity is determined by the number of entities or entity pairs linked by the relations.

target: The paper proposes a model-agnostic framework named MoCL, based on contrastive learning, to refine original representations for cross-domain NER.
prediction: The paper proposes a novel method for few-shot, speech-to-text translation named Word-Aligned COntrastive learning (WACO) which aims to bridge word-level representations across both modalities via contrastive learning.

log.reference: The paper proposes a novel method for few-shot, speech-to-text translation named Word-Aligned COntrastive learning (WACO) which aims to bridge word-level representations across both modalities via contrastive learning.

The authors propose TaCL (Token-aware Contrastive Learning), a novel continual pre-training approach that encourages BERT to learn an isotropic and discriminative distribution of token representations without requiring additional data.

This paper proposes a new Contrastive Neural Text generation framework, CoNT, that addresses three critical aspects that have been hindering the widespread adoption of contrastive learning in text generation tasks -- the creation of contrastive examples, the selection of a contrastive loss, and the strategy used during decoding.

The introduction of SimCTC, a simple contrastive learning framework that employs a pre-trained BERT model for mapping the input sequence to the representation space followed by three different loss function heads: Clustering head, Instance-CL head and Cluster-CL head.

The paper introduces a new GLobal and LOcal Hierarchy-aware Contrastive Framework (GLOF) that leverages the global hierarchy (static hierarchical structure containing all senses) and the local hierarchy (hierarchical sense label sequence corresponding to each instance) with the help of contrastive learning.

target: The authors propose a fine-tuned transformer-based model for problematic webpage classification and a novel webpage data collection strategy leveraging short-text hate speech datasets. They also introduce a custom GPT-4 few-shot prompt annotation scheme for webpage annotation.

The authors propose a new challenging NLP task of detecting political bias in Hindi news articles and present a transformer-based transfer learning method to fine-tune pre-trained networks for bias detection.

The authors propose an effective neural network-based technique for hostility detection in Hindi posts, viewing it as a multi-label multi-class classification problem. In this paper, the authors experimented with various neural network models - pre-trained word embeddings, stacked word embeddings, and fine-tuned XLM-RoBERTa model for hostility identification in Hindi. They also explored the effectiveness of back translation as a data augmentation technique to assist in fine-tuning of XLM-RoBERTa model for hostility identification.
The authors propose a supervised topic model that accounts for the heterogeneity and biases among different annotators when learning from crowds.

target: The authors present a new neural network architecture that incorporates document embeddings from a fine-tuned transformer-based model into a stacked long short-term memory (LSTM) and a fully connected linear (FCL) layer.
prediction: The authors propose a new LSTM variant, Global Context-Aware Attention LSTM (GCA-LSTM). This network is designed to selectively focus on the informative joints in the action sequence by using global contextual information and a recurrent attention mechanism for improved attention performance.

TRRN, a transformer-style relational reasoning network with dynamic memory updating, is presented to handle the challenges associated with modeling temporal network dependencies. This model uses multi-head self-attention to reason over a set of memories and uses policy networks with differentiable binary routers to estimate the possibility of each memory being activated and updates the memories dynamically.

The authors propose a series of neural network architectures for Chinese word segmentation that combine the Long Short-Term Memory Neural Network (LSTM) with the Conditional Random Field (CRF) method. They create character embeddings using the Skip-Gram model to serve as inputs for the LSTM model, the outputs of which are used in the CRF layer for word segmentation.

The authors propose a character-based neural language model that uses a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and a highway network over characters to feed into a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) Recurrent Neural Network language model (RNN-LM). This approach aims to generate predictions at word level utilizing character inputs.

This study proposes a regional CNN-LSTM model that uses a regional CNN to extract and weight useful affective information in individual sentences, and then uses an LSTM to sequentially integrate the information across regions for predicting VA ratings of texts.

target: This paper presents a novel approach, known as Joint Constrained Learning framework with Boundary-adjusting for Emotion-Cause Pair Extraction (JCB), which uses constrained learning to include the prior rules present in the data into the model optimization process. Furthermore, it adjusts the decision boundary of classifiers based on the relations between subtasks.
prediction: The authors propose an analogy between conversational emotion recognition process and a complete span of quantum measurement, which is then utilized in a quantum-like neural network.

log.reference: The authors propose an analogy between conversational emotion recognition process and a complete span of quantum measurement, which is then utilized in a quantum-like neural network.
The authors suggest a joint approach to emotion recognition and emotion cause detection that incorporates common-sense knowledge through adapted knowledge models along with multi-task learning.

The authors propose a face-sensitive image-to-emotional-text translation (FITE) method, that captures visual sentiment cues via facial expressions and selectively matches and fuses this with the target aspect in the textual domain.

The authors propose a method for transforming the emotional content in an image to a specified target emotion by blending the outputs from two networks, which can better transform fine details while still operating on the broader styles of the full image.

The authors propose a scalable approach for learning visual emotion representation and curate a web-derived large-scale dataset--StockEmotion--for this purpose. They use this dataset to train EmotionNet, regularized with joint text and visual embedding and text distillation.

target: To address the issue of semantic misalignment, a new framework named Concept Curation (CoCu) is introduced. This uses CLIP to compensate for missing semantics in image-text pairs by maintaining a concept archive with potential visually-matched concepts.
prediction: The authors propose a new task, unsupervised vision-language (VL) grammar induction, and a novel method, CLIORA, which simultaneously extracts a shared vision-language constituency tree structure grounded in both image and language modalities.

The authors propose a multi-granularity retrieval system to address these challenges, which comprises of three modules - a language parsing module to extract fine-grained attributes from language descriptions, a language-augmented multi-query vehicle track retrieval module to fuse information from multiple imperfect queries, and a target vehicle attributes enhancement module to fuse static and dynamic properties of the target vehicle.

The authors argue that language features deserve more attention in vision-language tasks, proving this through experiments which compare different word embeddings, language models, and embedding augmentation steps on five common VL tasks. They also propose a new Graph Oriented Vision-Language Embedding (GrOVLE), derived from Word2Vec using WordNet and a unique visual-language graph based on Visual Genome.

The paper investigates whether the addition of visual information can compensate for the missing source context in SiMT, and the impact of different multimodal approaches and visual features on state-of-the-art SiMT frameworks.

The authors investigate the out-of-distribution performance of end-to-end and neuro-symbolic systems in vision-and-language reasoning tasks using four types of generalization tests including a novel segment-combine test for multi-image queries.

target: The authors propose a spike sorting-free decoding method that directly models the distribution of extracted spike features using a mixture of Gaussians (MoG) to encode the uncertainty of spike assignments.
prediction: The authors propose an explicitly probabilistic approach, using latent-variable models to describe the distribution of waveforms produced by a single cell. They present a spectrum of models—from a single Gaussian distribution of waveforms for each cell to a mixture of hidden Markov models.

log.reference: The authors propose an explicitly probabilistic approach, using latent-variable models to describe the distribution of waveforms produced by a single cell. The authors introduce Bayesian estimators for the entropy of binary spike trains that allow for the flexible use of the statistical structure of neural spike responses. These estimators use prior distributions over spike words formed from mixtures of Dirichlet distributions centering around simple parametric models.

The authors propose a new state-space modeling framework suited to instances of high ambiguity and variability, addressing the trial-to-trial and moment-to-moment variability in neuron firing patterns that represent a particular environment or stimulus, and the rapid fluctuation between multiple representations in uncertain environments and tasks.

The authors reframe this problem as a statistical inference scenario in which the recorded voltage is a noisy sum of the spike trains of each neuron convolved with its associated spike waveform. They then propose a joint maximum-a-posteriori (MAP) estimation approach as a blind deconvolution problem where the coefficients are sparse.

An adaptive greedy filtering algorithm based on a discretized mark point-process model of ensemble spiking is proposed. This comes along with a precise statistical inference framework for identifying significant coordinated higher-order spiking activity.

target: The authors aim to analyze the relationship between relevance and conflict in online social link recommendations using the Friedkin-Johnsen model of opinion dynamics.
prediction: The study examines how perception bias in social networks influences user's satisfaction with their friend count. The analysis includes investigation of the friendship paradox and the introduction of a weighted perception bias metric that considers different effects of different friends on an individual's perception.

log.reference: The study examines how perception bias in social networks influences user's satisfaction with their friend count. The authors propose a predictive model that uses social media data to assess the strength of ties between users, linking social science theory of 'tie strength' to practice.

This study posits that the correlation between attributes and social connections can be explained through a hidden factor -- relationship type, and proposes to co-profile users' attributes and relationship types.

This paper develops two models that discuss the dissemination of public sentiment information within the context of heterogeneous networks and heterogeneous conditional networks, respectively. These models aim to show the effects of the connections among enterprise nodes in a science and technology network on the spread of science and technology information.

The researchers developed a stylised analytical model that investigates how successfully 'borrowing' connections from an established platform can facilitate the growth of a connected community in a new platform while preserving certain properties such as reciprocity and clustering.

target: The paper introduces the self-play and adversarial Generalized Eluder Coefficient (GEC) as new complexity measures for function approximation in MGs. They also propose two novel model-based posterior sampling methods for learning Nash equilibrium and adversarial MGs.
prediction: For episodic two-player zero-sum MGs, a novel posterior sampling algorithm is developed that uses general function approximation. The authors introduce a new complexity measure for MGs, the multi-agent decoupling coefficient.

The authors propose a mean-field game (MFG) approach for cloud resource management to handle a large number of users and applications. The solution includes function approximations to deal with the large state-action spaces in real-world serverless platforms.

The authors rephrase the problem of flocking as a Mean Field Game (MFG) where each individual chooses its acceleration depending on the population behavior. They utilize a combination of Deep Reinforcement Learning (RL) and Normalizing Flows (NF) to obtain a tractable solution that imposes only very weak assumptions.

The authors suggest ALMA, a decentralized and uncoupled anytime heuristic for the assignment problem, that is inspired by the human principle of altruism and does not require communication between participants.

The authors propose the ALMA-Learning algorithm, a multi-agent learning solution that bypasses traditional coordination problems. This solution is based on the ALMA heuristic used as a coordination mechanism for each stage game.

target: The authors propose handling continual learning tasks with neural processes (NPs), a class of meta-learners that encode different tasks into probabilistic distributions over functions which can also provide reliable uncertainty estimates. log.reference: This paper proposes a Cross-Task Knowledge Distillation framework that leverages the prediction results of one task as supervised signals to instruct another task, aiming to fill the gap in the existing MTL paradigm.

The authors introduce Meta Module Generation (MetaMG), a meta-learning method that generates a category module from a few examples, allowing a scalable classification network to recognize a new category without forgetting old categories.

The authors propose to improve the generalization of few-shot learning models for ED by transferring knowledge from open-domain word sense disambiguation and regularization of the representation learning for ED using a novel signal derived from dependency graphs.

This paper proposes a different approach to active learning, focusing on the data-incremental nature of the process. The key idea is to tune weight decay properly as data increases and enhance performance through knowledge distillation using a low-performance teacher model trained from the previous acquisition step.

The authors propose a deep multi-task learning framework with a novel design of shared-representation layer to aid in understanding and predicting cascades, effectively encoding the structure and the node sequence of the cascade.

The researchers propose a novel point cloud representation that is mathematically proven to be rigorously rotation-invariant, which produces unique and consistent representations for identical point clouds in different orientations. This study introduces a Teacher-Student Multimodal Fusion (TSMF) model that fuses skeleton and RGB modalities at the model level for indoor action recognition. The model employs a teacher network to transfer skeleton structural knowledge to a student network processing RGB modality.

The authors propose 3DSmoothNet, a full workflow that combines a siamese deep learning architecture and fully convolutional layers using a voxelized smoothed density value (SDV) representation to match 3D point clouds. The method uses SDVs computed per interest point and aligns them to the local reference frame for rotation invariance.

Authors propose an efficient and holistic pipeline, 3R-Depth, that deeply integrates an efficient 3D shape estimator with existing recognition (e.g., ResNets) and segmentation (e.g., MaskR-CNN) techniques, thereby allowing it to simultaneously learn the semantics and structure of a scene from a single depth image.

The authors look into the effects of memory on RNNs’ ability to approximate and optimize linear functionals, identifying a problem they dub the 'curse of memory' where increasing memory exacerbates approximation difficulty and slows training.
The study extends previous work by demonstrating that a RNN can learn a more complex CFL - a simple palindrome - by organizing its resources into a symbol-sensitive counting solution.

The authors propose a new recurrent architecture, Non-saturating Recurrent Unit (NRU), which relies on a memory mechanism and forgoes both saturating activation functions and saturating gates to further alleviate vanishing gradients.

target: The authors propose an efficient algorithm for latent variable modeling to leverage large amounts of dialogue data, avoiding the need for intermediate labels. target: The authors propose an efficient masked autoencoder for trajectory prediction (Traj-MAE) that better encapsulates the complex behaviors of agents in a driving context. The authors propose a two-step framework to learn relevant patient subgroups in an unsupervised way with a sequence-to-sequence autoencoder, and predict an outcome for separate patient populations in a multi-task learning framework, with each population as a separate task.

In this paper, the authors propose a simple extension of MAEs for spatiotemporal representation learning from videos by randomly masking out spacetime patches and reconstructing them using an autoencoder.

The paper introduces a new approach for OOD generalization by performing analogy-making and indirection in the functional space. To implement this, they propose FINE (Functional Indirection Neural Estimator), a framework that composes functions to map data input to output on-the-fly.

The authors propose ReAct — a simple and effective technique for reducing model overconfidence on OOD data, motivated by novel analysis on internal activations of neural networks that show distinctive signature patterns for OOD distributions.

This method evaluates the Mahalanobis distance of the gradients between the in-distribution and OOD data, and is assisted by a self-supervised binary classifier to guide the label selection to generate the gradients and maximize the Mahalanobis distance.

The authors suggest the need for Human Computer Interaction (HCI) researchers to explore the difficulties faced by refugees using a participatory approach, and to understand the organizational, methodological and practical challenges of working with refugee communities.

The authors propose to examine sex and themes related to it to enhance the understanding of human-computer interactions, suggesting that these areas have remained underexplored but are central to HCI.

The authors propose a new neural language model that includes an interpretable neuro-symbolic knowledge base (KB) in the form of a 'fact memory'. Each element of the fact memory is formed from a triple of vectors representing a KB entity or relation.

The paper presents an exploration of techniques that utilize both the topology and textual similarity between items as well as usage data collected by servers and page meta-information like title and size.

This paper proposes a new approach for website classification that uses the content of web pages together with the link structure between them to improve the accuracy of results. The approach uses Naive-Bayes models for each predefined webpage class, and an Extended version of Hidden Markov Model (HMMs) as website class models.

The authors propose a method for uncovering hierarchical structures within web pages based on in-page and cross-page link structures. A density-based clustering algorithm is developed to group densely linked web pages into semantic clusters.

target: The paper conducts a broad evaluation of methods for extracting confidence scores from language models fine-tuned with RLHF, and highlights the importance of the right prompting strategy in producing well-calibrated predictions.

In this paper, the authors introduce the concept of CKBERT (Chinese knowledge-enhanced BERT), which is a series of novel Chinese KEPLMs of various parameter sizes. Both relational and linguistic knowledge is effectively injected into CKBERT using two novel pre-training tasks — linguistic-aware masked language modeling and contrastive multi-hop relation modeling.

The aim of this study is to develop a new process called text-to-table that creates tables expressing the main content of a text. This process is entirely data-driven and does not require schema definitions. The authors utilize a sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) model fine-tuned from a pre-trained language model and develop a new method exploiting two additional table generation techniques: table constraint and table relation embeddings.

The authors present FewShotWoz, an NLG benchmark for few-shot learning in task-oriented dialog systems, and also propose the SC-GPT model that is pre-trained on a large annotated NLG corpus and fine-tuned only with a few domain-specific labels to adapt to new domains.

target: The authors investigate outlier dimensions and their relation to anisotropy in multiple pre-trained multilingual language models. The focus is on cross-lingual semantic similarity tasks, where sentence representations are particularly examined.

The authors propose an efficient data augmentation method, called text smoothing, that replaces a sentence's one-hot representation with a controllable smoothed representation obtained from a pre-trained masked language model.

The study proposes a method to ground language in learned representations using a standard representation learning algorithm -- autoencoding -- to facilitate decentralized multi-agent communication and coordination.
The authors introduce PhoBERT which comes in two versions, 'base' and 'large' making it the first public large-scale monolingual language models pre-trained specifically for Vietnamese.

The authors propose Hyper-X, a unified hypernetwork that bridges multilingual and multi-task learning with efficient adaptation and enables zero-shot transfer for novel languages and task-language combinations by generating weights for adapter modules based on both task and language embeddings.

target: The authors devised three novel text-based tasks for situational reasoning in the traffic domain (BDD-QA, TV-QA, HDT-QA), aiming to evaluate the ability of Language Models (LMs) to perform situational decision-making, reason about complex event causality and answer human driving exams, respectively.

The paper proposes a new methodology that involves a dynamic Bayesian network approach in modeling user knowledge within interactive narrative environments.

The paper proposes an expert system that autonomously monitors user interactions with the Vax/VMS operating system, recognizing inefficient command sequences, and voluntarily offers advice aimed at optimizing user interaction.

This paper proposes an approach that integrates an interactive visualisation with a flexible optimization engine to design a decision support system for production planning that includes energy efficiency and can be adjusted by experts without programming knowledge.

The authors propose a method to automatically explore potential payroll policies and find the optimal set by translating tax legislative knowledge into a formal representation for payroll calculations and compiling it into constraints for a solver to find optimal policies.

A new DL-based method, NSGZero, is proposed for learning a non-exploitable policy in NSGs. This method improves data efficiency by implementing neural Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) and enables decentralized control, thus making it scalable.

The authors propose a new planning backup that uses only the current value of a single successor state, reducing computation time. This new backup, referred to as a small backup, gives model-based reinforcement learning methods much finer control over their planning process than traditional methods.
