The paper proposes a multi-task learning approach that models the task-feature relationships. It posits that tasks should be related in terms of subsets of features, implying a co-cluster structure, and designs a regularization term accordingly.

This paper extends deep multi-task learning to the setting where there is no obvious overlap, decomposing any set of (architecture, task) pairs into a set of potentially related subproblems, and optimizing their sharing with a new efficient stochastic algorithm.

The authors propose a setting where multiple tasks are geographically located in different places and one task can synchronize data with others to leverage knowledge of related tasks resulting in an adaptive primal-dual algorithm that captures task-specific noise in adversarial learning and carries out a projection-free update with runtime efficiency.

target: This study validates that adversarial samples created by attack algorithms correlate strongly with a specific vector in high-dimensional inputs called Universal Adversarial Perturbations (UAPs) that can be computed without original training data. A data-agnostic adversarial detection framework is proposed based on this discovery.
prediction: The authors propose a new universal attack method, termed as class discriminative universal adversarial perturbation (CD-UAP), that generates a single perturbation which only fools a chosen group of classes, having limited influence on the remaining classes.

log.reference: The authors propose a new universal attack method, termed as class discriminative universal adversarial perturbation (CD-UAP), that generates a single perturbation which only fools a chosen group of classes, having limited influence on the remaining classes.

The authors propose ILFO (Intermediate Output-Based Loss Function Optimization) attack, a method to test the robustness of AdNNs by exploiting intermediate output to establish a relationship between input and energy consumption.

The authors propose an approach that uses adversarial perturbations in a self-supervised contrastive learning context, generating word-level adversarial attacks as hard positives during this learning process.

This paper proposes a simpler approach based on statistics on outputs from convolutional layers, with the aim to detect adversarial examples by analyzing whether they come from the same distribution as the normal examples. A cascade classifier is designed to efficiently detect adversarials.

The authors propose a unique and practical mechanism for detection of model piracy by uniquely characterizing the profile of a Deep Neural Network (DNN) model's decision boundary through its Universal Adversarial Perturbations (UAPs).

target: This study explores the use of transformer-based text classification, specifically fine-tuned RoBERTa transformer models, for clickbait spoiling and spoiler type classification, while also investigating an initial model for spoiler creation.
prediction: The authors introduce and study the task of clickbait spoiling, a process of generating a short informative text that satisfies the curiosity aroused by a clickbait post. They propose approaches to classify the type of spoiler needed (a passage or a phrase) and to generate appropriate spoilers.

log.reference: The authors introduce and study the task of clickbait spoiling, a process of generating a short informative text that satisfies the curiosity aroused by a clickbait post. They propose approaches to classify the type of spoiler needed (a passage or a phrase) and to generate appropriate spoilers.

The paper presents a machine learning model to detect clickbait articles. The authors propose that the degree of informality of a webpage is a strong indicator of it being a clickbait, which is a novel feature in the model.

This study explores a new proxy-caching framework that capitalizes on the query semantics of HTML forms and introduces form-based proxy caching. It also introduces two caching schemes: (i) traditional passive query caching, and (ii) active query caching where the proxy cache services a request by evaluating a query over the cache contents.

This paper presents a new proxy caching framework that leverages the query semantics of HTML forms and identifies two common classes of form-based queries: keyword-based queries and function-embedded queries. The authors propose two caching schemes: passive query caching and active query caching where the proxy can answer a request by running a query over the cache content.

This paper presents techniques and a tool for semi-automated identification and resolution of mismatches between service interfaces and protocols, and for generating adapter specifications. It focuses on finding mismatches of type of signature, merge/split, and extra/missing messages, and also identifies all ordering mismatches between service protocols by generating a mismatch tree.

target: The authors propose a simple and effective sharpness-based detector to distinct adversarial samples by maximizing the loss increment within the region where the inference sample is located.
prediction: The authors propose a frequency-tuned universal attack method that computes universal perturbations in the frequency domain, adapting the perturbations to the local frequency content.

log.reference: The authors propose a frequency-tuned universal attack method that computes universal perturbations in the frequency domain, adapting the perturbations to the local frequency content.

The authors propose a novel approach for data-free scenarios that crafts UAPs using class impressions to emulate the effect of data samples and a neural network-based generative model that utilizes these class impressions to craft UAPs.

The authors suggest automatically generating adversarial negative training data to aid ranking and evaluation models to learn features beyond content similarity. They propose two approaches, mask-and-fill and keyword-guided, that generate negative examples which are high in content similarity with the contexts but are incoherent, inappropriate, or not fluent.

The authors propose a new adversarial learning paradigm--Reverse Engineering of Deceptions (RED)--that allows to estimate adversarial perturbations and recover the original images from adversarially perturbed images. The authors also identify prediction alignment and proper data augmentation as key principles for RED and propose a Class-Discriminative Denoising based RED framework, termed CDD-RED.

This study pioneers the investigation of UAPs in the context of image retrieval systems aiming to make the system return irrelevant images to a query. It proposes a novel method to generate retrieval-against UAPs to disrupt the neighbourhood relationships of image features thereby degrading the corresponding ranking metric.

target: The paper proposes Contrastive Novelty-Augmented Learning (CoNAL), a two-step method that generates Out-Of-Distribution (OOD) examples representative of novel classes and trains to decrease confidence on them.
prediction: The authors identify two key properties related to the contrastive loss: alignment of features from positive pairs and uniformity of the induced distribution of the (normalized) features on the hypersphere. They also introduce an optimizable metric to quantify each property.

log.reference: The authors identify two key properties related to the contrastive loss: alignment of features from positive pairs and uniformity of the induced distribution of the (normalized) features on the hypersphere. They also introduce an optimizable metric to quantify each property.

The authors propose an unsupervised network embedding method called SCE, which only uses negative samples for training. The method is based on a new contrastive objective that is inspired by the sparsest cut problem and includes a Laplacian smoothing trick to solve the underlying optimization problem.

The authors devise a feature-level data manipulation, differing from data augmentation, to enhance contrastive learning. They also introduce a visualization scheme for positive and negative score distribution to analyze, interpret, and understand the learning process.
The paper introduces a new family of adversarial examples for contrastive learning and uses these examples to define a new adversarial training algorithm for SSL, known as CLAE.

The authors propose a new model named Critical Semantic-Consistent Learning (CSCL) that reduces discrepancies in both domain-wise and category-wise distributions, by highlighting transferable domain-wise knowledge and neglecting untransferable ones.

target: EgoObjects is introduced, which is a large-scale egocentric dataset for fine-grained object understanding. It includes instance-level identifiers for each object and captures the same object under varied conditions like background complexities, surrounding objects, distances, lighting, and camera motion.
prediction: The authors propose a hierarchical approach to visual recognition based on BoVW that jointly learns suitable mid- and top-level representations, using a max-margin learning framework to directly handle the multiclass case at both levels of abstraction.

log.reference: The authors propose a hierarchical approach to visual recognition based on BoVW that jointly learns suitable mid- and top-level representations, using a max-margin learning framework to directly handle the multiclass case at both levels of abstraction.

The paper presents a method that respects contextuality to compose classifiers of known visual concepts, founded on the idea that classifiers occupy a smooth space where compositional transforms can be modeled.

The authors aim to study the effectiveness of these existing unsupervised models on real-world images rather than proposing a new algorithm. They introduce four complexity factors to quantitatively measure the distributions of object- and scene-level biases in appearance and geometry for datasets with human annotations.

The paper conducts a comprehensive investigation into the transferability of learned representations of various contrastive approaches across multiple downstream datasets, and object detection tasks on MSCOCO and VOC0712.

To bridge this gap, this paper introduces Tracking Any Object (TAO), a diverse dataset comprising 2,907 high-resolution videos captured in different environments and featuring an extensive vocabulary of 833 categories, developed using a bottom-up approach.

target: The authors introduce Quantum-Gaussian Process-Upper Confidence Bound (Q-GP-UCB), the first Bayesian optimization algorithm capable of achieving an upper bound of O(polylog T), which is considerably smaller than the regret lower bound of Omega(sqrt(T)) in a classical framework.
prediction: The authors propose two Bayesian optimization algorithms (CV-UCB and CV-TS) with theoretical performance guarantees to maximize the CVaR of black-box functions. These algorithms are based on principles of optimism in the face of uncertainty and Thompson sampling respectively.

log.reference: The authors propose two Bayesian optimization algorithms (CV-UCB and CV-TS) with theoretical performance guarantees to maximize the CVaR of black-box functions. These algorithms are based on principles of optimism in the face of uncertainty and Thompson sampling respectively.

The authors propose a different approach to the equilibrium-finding problem. They give an efficient practical algorithm that factors a large payoff matrix into a product of two matrices that are typically dramatically sparser, reformulating the problem as a linear program with size only a logarithmic factor worse than counterfactual regret minimization.

The authors propose a scenario where the firms use no-regret learning algorithms, specifically online mirror descent (OMD), with decreasing step sizes to review their pricing strategy based on consumers' responsiveness to the current posted prices provided by an oracle.

This study proposes the first black-box approach to obtain long-term memory guarantees for online learning by reducing the problem to achieving typical switching regret. The work has also developed various algorithms to solve the classical expert problem with a particular regret bound.

The study introduces GP-UCB, an upper-confidence based algorithm for Gaussian process optimization and also proposes to frame the problem in terms of maximal information gain which establishes a connection between Gaussian process optimization and experimental design.

target: The authors propose a new estimator called Rand-Proj-Spatial, which improves encoding by projecting the client vectors onto a random $k$-dimensional subspace using Subsampled Randomized Hadamard Transform (SRHT). The authors also propose a practical variant of Rand-Proj-Spatial for scenarios where correlation information is not available to the server.
prediction: The authors introduce a framework for automatic configuration of spectral dimensionality reduction methods, a mutual information measure to assess the quality of discovered embedded spaces, and a data projection method based on a fully automatic and dynamically adjustable Radial Basis Function network to overcome the mapping deficiencies.

log.reference: The authors introduce a framework for automatic configuration of spectral dimensionality reduction methods, a mutual information measure to assess the quality of discovered embedded spaces, and a data projection method based on a fully automatic and dynamically adjustable Radial Basis Function network to overcome the mapping deficiencies.

The authors bring forth the idea of analysing a variant of the Sinclair, Banerjee, and Yu (2019) algorithm for reinforcement learning in metric spaces anchored on a parameter called the zooming dimension, which is always smaller than the covering dimension.
The authors propose a new solution to dimensionality reduction based on semidefinite programming to analyze high-dimensional data that lies on or near a low-dimensional manifold.

This study proposes a topology-preserving dimensionality reduction method that optimizes the orthogonal projection to lower-dimensional subspace by minimizing the discrepancy between the persistent diagrams of the original data and the projection.

This study proposes a novel dimensionality reduction algorithm that integrates both global and local structures. It introduces a least squares formulation for dimensionality reduction, facilitating this integration.

target: The authors propose EconBERTa, a large language model pretrained on scientific publications in economics, and they also introduce ECON-IE, a new dataset of economics abstracts for Named Entity Recognition (NER).
prediction: The authors examine how models like GPT-J, BERT, RoBERTa, and GloVe encode character-level information by using classifiers to predict the presence or absence of certain characters based on token embeddings.

log.reference: The authors examine how models like GPT-J, BERT, RoBERTa, and GloVe encode character-level information by using classifiers to predict the presence or absence of certain characters based on token embeddings.

This study proposes Unified pre-trained Language Model (UniLM) that can be fine-tuned for both natural language understanding and generation tasks by using three types of language modeling tasks: unidirectional, bidirectional, and sequence-to-sequence prediction.
The authors define simple heuristics to construct incoherent examples as an investigative tool to understand BERT model family responses.

The authors propose to study the English BERT family with two probing techniques, and propose a hypothesis that fine-tuning influences classification performance by increasing the distances between examples associated with different labels.

The authors present a unique method of studying the BERT-space by inducing a 'pseudoword' as an equivalent for a static embedding in the input layer, and then doing masked prediction of a word in the sentence to inspect the geometry of BERT-space locally around individual instances.

target: The authors propose using Normalized Mutual Information (NMI) for abstract segmentation, assuming that conclusions are strongly semantically linked with preceding premises, and introduce an unsupervised approach called GreedyCAS that places two segmentation boundaries by optimizing the NMI score.
prediction: The authors present a novel approach to tackling perceptual grouping problems, in which such problems are expressed as a global optimization problem. They also introduce an original neural network model called a pulsed neural network.

log.reference: The authors present a novel approach to tackling perceptual grouping problems, in which such problems are expressed as a global optimization problem. They also introduce an original neural network model called a pulsed neural network.

The paper introduces f-BRS (feature backpropagating refinement scheme), an optimization approach for interactive segmentation. Unlike the original BRS, f-BRS operates with respect to auxiliary variables and not the inputs of the network. This reduces the parts of the network that need to run forward and backward passes.

The authors propose a new algorithm that converts user-annotations into interaction maps and then uses a convolutional neural network to output an initial segmentation map. To address mislabeling, they develop a Backpropagating Refinement Scheme (BRS) to correct such mislabeled pixels.

The authors propose an approach that addresses these challenges within a perceptual organization framework, leveraging both binocular and monocular sources of information and using geometric and color data from the scene for grouping.

The paper proposes a novel segmentation strategy, co-heterogenous and adaptive segmentation (CHASe), which uses a small labeled cohort of single-phase data to adapt to any unlabeled cohort of heterogeneous multi-phase data, including new clinical scenarios and pathologies. The strategy synthesizes appearance-based semi-supervision, mask-based adversarial domain adaptation, and pseudo-labeling and introduces co-heterogeneous training, a combination of co-training and hetero-modality learning.

target: The authors propose TopWORDS-Poetry, an unsupervised method to simultaneously perform reliable text segmentation and word discovery for classical Chinese poetry without a pre-given vocabulary or training corpus.
prediction: The study proposes TopWORDS-Seg, a novel method based on Bayesian inference which is capable of simultaneous text segmentation and word discovery in open-domain Chinese texts and doesn't require any training corpus or domain vocabulary.

log.reference: The study proposes TopWORDS-Seg, a novel method based on Bayesian inference which is capable of simultaneous text segmentation and word discovery in open-domain Chinese texts and doesn't require any training corpus or domain vocabulary.
The authors propose a new corpus study, developing and automatically extracting three features to analyze the classical character of Chinese poetry across the 20th century.

The paper proposes a language tagging template named POC-NLW (position of a character within an n-length word), and constructs a two-stage statistical model for Chinese word segmentation. The basic word segmentation is based on n-gram language model, and a Hidden Markov tagger based on the POC-NLW template is used for out-of-vocabulary (OOV) word identification.

The paper introduces a new approach to Chinese word segmentation, positing it as a classification task where character-boundaries (CB's) in a string are classified into either word-boundaries (WB's) or non-word-boundaries. Distributional properties of CB's among character strings are utilized to predict which CB's are WB's.

The authors hypothesize that human performance in novel language tasks is better represented by flexible inference through the composition of basic computational motifs. They introduce a new model, GibbsComplete, which composes two computational motifs: masked and autoregressive word prediction.

target: The authors propose a neural-network-based system that scores and extracts insights from a marketing content design. This system includes a multimodal neural network that predicts the attractiveness of marketing contents, and a post-hoc attribution method that generates actionable insights to improve content in specific marketing locations.
prediction: The authors propose a prototype-guided attribute-wise interpretable compatibility modeling scheme (PAICM), which integrates latent compatible/incompatible prototype learning and compatibility modeling with the Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) framework.

log.reference: The authors propose a prototype-guided attribute-wise interpretable compatibility modeling scheme (PAICM), which integrates latent compatible/incompatible prototype learning and compatibility modeling with the Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) framework.

The authors address the product selection problem by proposing an algorithmic framework for k-Most Promising Products (k-MPP) query, which selects products for targeted marketing with the highest expected total customer count.

The authors introduce a novel approach to detecting unorganized malicious attacks in recommender systems, envisioning it as a matrix completion task. They propose the Unorganized Malicious Attacks detection (UMA) method which utilizes the alternating splitting augmented Lagrangian method.

The authors propose a method called Policy-Guided Path Reasoning (PGPR) that aims to generate recommendations through an interpretable causal inference procedure, supported by actual paths in a knowledge graph. The method combines recommendation and interpretability.

The authors propose to boost the performance of PFCM by fully exploring related entities and their relations involved in PFCM. They present a novel metapath-guided personalized fashion compatibility modeling, named MG-PFCM, which builds a heterogeneous graph unifying three types of entities (users, items, attributes) and their relations.

target: The authors propose a new approach termed as 'ray conditioning' which is a geometry-free alternative that relaxes the photo-consistency constraint. It generates multi-view images by conditioning a 2D GAN on a light field prior.
prediction: The paper describes a hybrid method for estimating the 3D shape of glossy surfaces that combines both diffuse and specular components by pairing a projector with a display.

log.reference: The paper describes a hybrid method for estimating the 3D shape of glossy surfaces that combines both diffuse and specular components by pairing a projector with a display.
This paper proposes using the real projective plane as a representation tool for exploiting symmetries in reflectance due to its property where each point represents a visible surface normal.

The authors propose a method for specular surface reconstruction that combines Dynamic Programming and Markov Random Fields, requiring only the relative position of the environment points to compute approximate normals and infer shape from them.

The paper formally relates terrain elevation and observed cast shadows and uses an optimization framework to refine surface estimates using shadowing constraints from one or more images, which is particularly beneficial for resolving the voids in SRTM digital elevation models.

The paper proposes constructing a 3D linear image basis for arbitrary illumination conditions from images of a moving object under static lighting, leveraging the motion-caused illumination variance on the object surface, and utilizing a geotensity constraint to establish correspondence between input images.

target: The authors propose AttDef, an efficient attribution-based pipeline to defend against two insertion-based poisoning attacks, BadNL and InSent. The method relies on identifying tokens with larger attribution scores as potential triggers since they contribute more to the false prediction results and are more likely to be poison triggers.
prediction: The authors present a unified framework for solving batch policy poisoning attacks that addresses this security threat.

log.reference: The authors present a unified framework for solving batch policy poisoning attacks that addresses this security threat.

This study investigates the ability of a 'blind attacker' to limit a machine learner's performance using a data injection attack, even in situations where the attacker has no access to the learner's training data or the distribution from which it is drawn.
The authors in this contribution focus on malicious participant behavior, stating that an atomic exchange of common data is not possible under the assumption of malicious participants.

The authors construct a generic poisoning framework for online RL and propose a strategic poisoning algorithm called Vulnerability-Aware Adversarial Critic Poison (VA2C-P), which is designed to work for most policy-based deep RL agents. This closes the gap where no poisoning method exists for policy-based RL agents.

This paper proposes a generic data poisoning attack framework, I2Attack, for domain adaptation. This framework manipulates only source examples within domain adaptation algorithms and does so in a way that is unnoticeable, indirect, and invisible, thus aiming to degrade prediction performance on the target domain by maximizing label-informed domain discrepancy.

target: This paper aims to assess the utility of machine-generated rationales for human users and proposes a new score, GEN-U, to evaluate the human utility of these rationales.

The authors propose a new model called Boolean Latent Semantic Indexing, which combines Singular Value Decomposition and Boolean query formulation to address issues in existing systems.

The authors propose Latent Meaning Cells (LMC), a deep latent variable model that learns contextualized representations of words by combining local lexical context and metadata. Metadata can refer both to granular and more global context.

The authors propose a bilingual Latent Semantic Analysis (bLSA) based framework for crosslingual language model adaptation that enforces a one-to-one topic correspondence during training. This allows for efficient transfer of latent topics between languages and rapid bootstrapping of LSA models for new languages.

The paper introduces a new strategy named 'Latent Semantic Indexing' for dealing with vocabulary problem. This approach automatically organizes text objects into a semantic structure that is more suitable for matching user requests, leveraging the implicit higher-order structure in terms-text object associations.

target: The authors investigate the impact of compositionality on imitation learning in language emergence and explore the relationship between the learning algorithm and the nature of language produced.

The authors propose a novel non-parametric method which does not require changes to the model structure that introduces two k-nearest-neighbor (KNN) modules: one that memorizes the human feedback and the other that balances the usage of the historical human feedback and original NMT models adaptively.

The paper introduces the idea of k-nearest-neighbor machine translation (kNN-MT), which predicts tokens using a nearest-neighbor classifier over a large datastore of cached examples, utilizing representations from a neural translation model for similarity search.

This paper proposes Fast kNN-MT, which constructs a significantly smaller datastore for nearest neighbor search. For each word in a source sentence, Fast kNN-MT selects its nearest token-level neighbors, and at each decoding step, the search space is limited to target tokens corresponding to the previously selected reference source tokens.

The paper formulates HTC as a sequence generation task and introduces a sequence-to-tree framework (Seq2Tree) to model the hierarchical label structure. A constrained decoding strategy with dynamic vocabulary is designed to ensure the label consistency of the results.

target: The authors propose Ranger, a task-agnostic toolkit that combines the effect of a treatment on multiple tasks into one statistical evaluation, making it possible to compare different metrics and compute a summary effect.

The paper proposes a novel framework to replace the classification task in one-stage detectors with a ranking task, and adopting the Average-Precision loss (AP-loss) for the ranking problem.
The paper proposes a new measure, τGAP, which combines the features of τAP and ρ, focusing on both head weight and gap sensitivity.
This paper proposes a new rank correlation coefficient, AP correlation (Τap), based on average precision. This new statistic provides more weight to errors at high rankings.

target: The paper introduces AlignScore, a unified, holistic metric based on a general function of information alignment between any two given text pieces. This metric is meant to assess a variety of factual inconsistency scenarios.

A novel framework for word alignment is proposed that incorporates synonym information gathered from monolingual linguistic resources into a bilingual probabilistic model.
The authors propose an approach that uses multiple preprocessing schemes to improve statistical word alignments.

The authors propose a new method for tuple alignment in regression that aligns values recorded within a short period (time constraint) and those that coincide well with the regression model (model constraint).
The authors propose semantically justified measures that can offer maximal precision and maximal recall for correct and complete alignments, overcoming the limitations of existing measures.

target: The authors propose to conduct a fairer comparison of the generalization performance of few-shot fine-tuning and in-context learning by controlling for the model size, number of examples and number of parameters.

The authors propose a robust prefix-tuning framework that maintains the efficiency and modularity of prefix-tuning by using the layerwise activations of the language model by correctly-classified training data as the standard for additional prefix finetuning.

The authors present TABT5, an encoder-decoder model that generates natural language text based on tables and textual inputs. A programmatic solution to generate product advertising headlines using retail content is proposed, applying Reinforcement Learning (RL) Policy gradient methods on Transformer-based Masked Language Models.

The authors propose Compositional Fine-Tuning (CFT), an approach that decomposes a target task into component tasks, and then fine-tunes smaller LMs on a curriculum of such component tasks. This approach bypasses the need for large pretrained LMs.

target: In this paper, both strengths and weaknesses of attention layers are examined in terms of representational power, focusing on intrinsic parameters such as width, depth, and embedding dimension.

The paper proposes Matrix Encoding Network (MatNet), a new type of neural network specifically designed to conveniently process parameters of complex CO problems that are specified in a matrix form.
The authors propose to unify normalization layers and activation functions into a single computation graph, and evolve its structure starting from low-level primitives.
This study highlights batch normalization as an effective strategy to prevent rank collapse in both linear and ReLU networks.

The study establishes that the number of layers and the width of multi-layered connectionist models are crucial for their performance; particularly, increasing width yields better results than adding layers.

target: The paper proposes NESTA (NEuro-Symbolic Textual Agent), a modular system that combines a generic semantic parser with a rule induction system to learn abstract, interpretable rules as policies.

The authors propose a definition of partial order between expressivity based on generalisation performance across different language games. The authors propose a neurally inspired computational model that is capable of reasoning about linguistic action and event descriptions, like those found in news stories.
The paper proposes a goal-based analysis of human personality traits and develops a process model based on the goal-tree and planning/counterplanning strategies initially used in the POLITICS system.

The key idea in this study consists of analyzing experimental results from a psychological investigation into the methods of structure organization, generalization, and goal setting in a given situation, and investigating a semiotic system to form generalized imitation models as the basis for human decision-making.

target: This research aims to develop methods for identifying animate entities visually in comics using annotation experiments.

The authors present a two-tier model for the description of morphological, syntactic and semantic variations of multi-word terms, specifically tailored for term normalization.

The authors propose to examine and model the impact of verb polysemy on thematic fit by presenting a new dataset of human ratings on high vs. low-polysemy verbs matched for verb frequency, with differently fitting and frequency patient role-fillers.
The authors suggest leveraging an existing set of lexical categories as a novel prediction method for lexical structure acquisition.
The authors propose FLUSH, a Flexible Lexicon Utilizing Specialized and Hierarchical knowledge, as a new flexible and knowledge-based lexicon design that allows for a broad phrasal coverage.

target: The authors propose WeLT, a cost-sensitive fine-tuning approach to deal with class imbalance in biomedical NER tasks. This approach introduces re-scaled class weights to improve the fine-tuning of BioPLMs.

The authors propose an LF-based bi-level optimization framework called WISDOM to overcome the limitations of previous methods. WISDOM learns a joint model on the labeled dataset used for LF induction and any unlabeled data in a semi-supervised manner, and more critically, reweighs each LF according to its goodness, influencing its contribution to the semi-supervised loss using a robust bi-level optimization algorithm.

The authors propose an end-to-end framework for dealing with label-noise learning without anchor points, by optimizing two metrics: the cross entropy loss between the noisy label and the predicted probability by the neural network, and the volume of the simplex formed by the columns of the transition matrix.

The novel technique proposed in this study, called Learning Feature Engineering (LFE), automates feature engineering in classification tasks by learning the effectiveness of applying a transformation on numerical features from past experiences.
The authors propose a new framework that generalizes the LUPI paradigm, specifically aimed at minimizing the distribution mismatch between the errors made in images and privileged data.

target: A unified generative model called UniCOQE is proposed to solve the COQE task in one shot. A generative template is designed where all the comparative tuples are concatenated as the target output sequence and a new 'predict-and-assign' training paradigm is introduced to alleviate order bias.

The paper introduces a new Zero-Shot Adaptive Transfer method for slot tagging that uses the slot description for transferring reusable concepts across domains, providing efficient training without requiring explicit concept alignments.

This paper proposes a framework named DSCGN based on a pre-trained language model with a noise-robust loss function that predicts personal attributes from conversations without requiring labeled utterances, and by mining personal attribute knowledge from both unlabeled utterances and external resources to fine-tune the language model.

The authors propose a view-independent relational model (VIRM) which inspects a CAD model of an object from different viewpoints to identify relatively view-independent relationships among component parts of the object, represented in the form of a hypergraph.

The authors propose Dynamic Schema Graph Fusion Network (DSGFNet), a novel model that generates a dynamic schema graph to explicitly fuse the prior slot-domain membership relations and the dialogue-aware dynamic slot relations and uses schemata to facilitate knowledge transfer to new domains.

target: The authors propose Geo-Seq2seq, a sequence-to-sequence model for Twitter user geolocation that rewrites noisy, multilingual user-provided location strings into structured English location names.
prediction: The authors propose a probabilistic model that characterizes how individuals change or retain their areas of expertise, taking into account three factors: the personality of the expert in exploring new areas, the similarity between the new area and the expert's current areas, and the popularity of the new area.

log.reference: The authors propose a probabilistic model that characterizes how individuals change or retain their areas of expertise, taking into account three factors: the personality of the expert in exploring new areas, the similarity between the new area and the expert's current areas, and the popularity of the new area.
The study aims to validate the assumption of the social aspect in tagging systems by examining social interactions using real-world data from a public social tagging system, bibs.

A novel system for 'new-Web' search is proposed, which is based on links retrieved from the Twitter micro-blogging service. When a Twitter message contains a URL, the message is used as a description of the URL's target.
The authors propose a method for estimating the credibility of posted information based on users' geographic posting tendencies and votes by other users.

This paper shares the authors' experience on executing a variety of micro-blogging queries on two popular graph databases, Neo4j and Sparksee, which are aimed at reflecting popular applications of micro-blog data.

target: The authors introduce a new sketch-photo correspondence benchmark (PSC6k) and propose a self-supervised method for learning dense correspondences between sketch-photo pairs, leveraging a spatial transformer network to estimate the warp flow between the latent representations of a sketch and photo.
prediction: The authors explore the capability of features derived from deep neural networks to identify artistic styles in paintings and propose a compact binary representation of the paintings.

log.reference: The authors explore the capability of features derived from deep neural networks to identify artistic styles in paintings and propose a compact binary representation of the paintings.

The proposed approach trains compact feed-forward convolutional networks to generate multiple samples of the same texture of arbitrary size and to transfer artistic style from one image to another, reducing computational burden by moving it to a learning stage.

This work proposes a new framework for CSS that addresses the issues of forgetting in the decoder head and the entanglement of old and new knowledge in intermediate features through the introduction of two novel constraints: a structure preserving loss and a feature projection module.

The authors propose the first end-to-end network for online video style transfer, which generates temporally coherent stylized video sequences in near real-time. Key aspects of this approach include an efficient network that incorporates short-term coherence and a method for propagating short-term coherence to long-term to ensure consistency over longer periods of time.

This work characterizes the instability of style transfer methods and proposes a recurrent convolutional network for real-time video style transfer which incorporates a temporal consistency loss to overcome instability.

target: The authors propose a solution, TechCD, exploiting a pedagogical knowledge concept graph (KCG) as a mediator connecting various domains to transfer student cognitive signals from established domains to the zero-shot cold-start domain.
prediction: The authors propose a new learning paradigm, named SEED (SElf-SupErvised Distillation), where a larger network (teacher) transfers its representational knowledge to a smaller architecture (student) in a self-supervised fashion.

log.reference: The authors propose a new learning paradigm, named SEED (SElf-SupErvised Distillation), where a larger network (teacher) transfers its representational knowledge to a smaller architecture (student) in a self-supervised fashion.

This paper aims to develop a recommendation method strong on both normal biased and debiased tests. The authors propose an Interpolative Distillation (InterD) framework, which interpolates the biased and unbiased models at the user-item pair level by distilling a student model.

The authors propose an efficient and reliable self-distillation framework called Self-Distillation from Last Mini-Batch (DLB) which rearranges sequential sampling to constrain half of each mini-batch to coincide with the previous and subsequent iterations thereby guiding training stability and consistency.

The authors propose a new method for KD where only a limited number of unlabeled training samples and a black-box teacher are at disposal. The core idea is to generate a diverse set of out-of-distribution synthetic images using MixUp and a conditional variational auto-encoder to expand the training dataset.

The authors propose a comprehensive, interventional distillation (CID) method that captures both sample and class representations while removing bias through causal intervention. The softened logits, typically used as training targets, are considered as context information to eliminate biased knowledge.

target: In this paper, the authors propose the first Unsupervised Domain Generalization framework for Face Anti-Spoofing (UDG-FAS) which exploits large amounts of easily accessible unlabeled data to learn generalizable features for enhancing the low-data regime of FAS. The authors propose a novel Split-Rotation-Merge module and search cross-domain neighbors method.
prediction: The authors propose an unsupervised image-to-image translation framework that maximizes a domain-specific variational information bound and also learns the target domain-invariant representation of the two domains.

log.reference: The authors propose an unsupervised image-to-image translation framework that maximizes a domain-specific variational information bound and also learns the target domain-invariant representation of the two domains.

This paper introduces a Non-Adversarial Mapping (NAM) method that separates the task of target domain generative modeling from the cross-domain mapping task. Unlike existing methods, NAM relies on a pre-trained generative model of the target domain and aligns each source image with an image synthesized from the target domain, while jointly optimizing the domain mapping function.

The authors propose an adversarial learning method for domain adaptation in the context of semantic segmentation, considering segmentations as structured outputs with spatial similarities across domains.

The authors propose a new dataset, LandMarkDA, to study the adaptation between landmark place recognition models trained with different artistic image styles, such as photos, paintings and drawings. They also experiment with recent shallow and deep adaptation networks based on using Maximum Mean Discrepancy to bridge the domain gap, and propose a new DA method that combines the artistic image style-transfer with deep discrepancy-based networks.

The authors propose a new model called Variational Recurrent Adversarial Deep Domain Adaptation (VRADA) that is built on a Variational Recurrent Neural Network (VRNN) and trained adversarially to capture and transfer complex domain-invariant temporal relationships.

target: The authors present a face editing framework that merges a 3D face model with StyleGAN vector-quantization to help learn multi-level semantic facial control. This strategy allows more semantic facial representations, for instance, teeth and pupils, to be modeled beyond what can be achieved with 3D tracking priors.
prediction: The authors incorporate Gabor-features into SRC, leading to the creation of Gabor-feature based SRC (GSRC). This helps to make the occlusion dictionary compressible, and a specific Gabor occlusion dictionary computing algorithm is proposed.

log.reference: The authors incorporate Gabor-features into SRC, leading to the creation of Gabor-feature based SRC (GSRC). This helps to make the occlusion dictionary compressible, and a specific Gabor occlusion dictionary computing algorithm is proposed.

The authors propose SmileNet, a novel smiling face detection framework that does not require pre-processing and is capable of simultaneously performing face detection and smile recognition. This is achieved through a single Fully Convolutional Neural Network (FCNN).
The S-AdaBoost algorithm, a variant of AdaBoost to handle real world environment, is the main idea discussed in the paper and is applied in a Face Identification System for Airports (FISA).

The paper presents a novel data-driven approach to the problem of face identification, casting it as a sequence generation problem. The authors adopt a variant of the popular Transformer model to predict the edges associated with the same face in a natural order.

The authors present a novel scale-aware progressive training mechanism, ProgressFace, inspired by curriculum learning, that gradually learns from large face instances towards smaller ones. The large faces provide a good initialization for learning smaller faces. In addition, an auxiliary anchor-free enhancement module is introduced to further assist in learning small faces.

target: The authors propose a face recognition distillation method, ICD-Face, that introduces intra-class compactness distillation into the existing distillation framework.
prediction: The authors propose a new inhomogeneous Gibbs model, learned through the minimax entropy principle, for face modeling. This model learns local statistics of facial features, with distribution learning occurring in a subspace reduced by PCA.

log.reference: The authors propose a new inhomogeneous Gibbs model, learned through the minimax entropy principle, for face modeling. This model learns local statistics of facial features, with distribution learning occurring in a subspace reduced by PCA.

Two novel techniques are proposed for face recognition: Dual Objective Feature Selection to learn and select only discriminant features, and Scaled Euclidean Classification to exploit within-class information for smarter matching.

The authors propose the use of familial social relationships as context for not only recognizing people but also for identifying the social relationships between pairs of people. They introduce a novel model for representing the interaction between social relationship, facial appearance, and identity.

The authors introduce a novel training method, called Multibatch, designed for similarity learning. It enables the creation of an invariant 'face signature' using pairs of 'similar' and 'not similar' face images.

The study proposes BioMetricNet, a novel framework for deep unconstrained face verification which introduces a regularized metric for comparing facial features. Instead of imposing a precise metric, the decision space is shaped by learning a latent representation that maps matching and non-matching pairs onto clearly separated well-behaved target distributions.

target: The study proposes a weakly supervised method for point cloud segmentation, called Multimodal Interlaced Transformer (MIT), that uses two encoders and one decoder for jointly considering 2D and 3D data. The two encoders compute self-attended features for 3D point clouds and 2D multi-view images, while the decoder implements interlaced 2D-3D cross-attention and carries out implicit feature fusion.
prediction: This paper uncovers the intertwined nature of scene completion and semantic labeling, and proposes the Semantic Scene Completion Network (SSCNet), an end-to-end 3D convolutional network, for semantic scene completion from a single depth image.

log.reference: This paper uncovers the intertwined nature of scene completion and semantic labeling, and proposes the Semantic Scene Completion Network (SSCNet), an end-to-end 3D convolutional network, for semantic scene completion from a single depth image.

The authors propose the first deep learning-based, edge-aware technique for consolidating point clouds, designing the network to specifically handle local patches of points and focusing on edge consolidation.

The authors propose the design of self-attention networks, particularly the Point Transformer, for 3D point cloud processing tasks such as semantic scene segmentation, object part segmentation, and object classification.

The paper proposes a novel end-to-end trainable deep architecture for object detection in point clouds, called Attentional PointNet. This technique extends the theory of visual attention mechanisms to 3D point clouds and introduces a new recurrent 3D Localization Network module to identify regions of interest, thus reducing the number of points to be processed and inference time.
The authors propose a novel end-to-end approach for unstructured point cloud semantic segmentation, named 3P-RNN, to exploit the inherent contextual features.

target: The key idea is the initiation of a new contrastive learning framework, FOCAL, which extracts comprehensive features from multimodal time-series sensing signals through self-supervised training. It encodes each modality into a factorized latent space of shared features and private features, and applies a temporal structural constraint for modality features.
prediction: A new framework is proposed, coined as self-supervised collaborative learning, to synthesize missing modalities for medical images. The method utilizes all available information correlated to the target modality from multi-source-modality images to generate any missing modality in a single model.

log.reference: A new framework is proposed, coined as self-supervised collaborative learning, to synthesize missing modalities for medical images. The method utilizes all available information correlated to the target modality from multi-source-modality images to generate any missing modality in a single model.
This paper proposes the application of a recursive neural network (RNN) to model the compositional aspect of language for identifying political ideologies from text at a phrase and sentence level.
In their prototype CONCAT, the authors propose using neural network technology to learn about the relations within the concept and document space of an existing domain.

The authors propose the Recurrent Neural Network-based IDF Biterm Topic Model (RIBSTM), an approach that incorporates Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) for relationship learning between words and Inverse Document Frequency (IDF) for filtering high-frequency words.

The authors propose an edge-editing approach for graph construction, wherein relations in a document are treated as a graph and iteratively built by editing edges of an initial graph. Each edge is represented with document context information by a pretrained transformer model and graph context information by a Graph Convolutional Neural Network model.

target: To address these issues, the authors introduce an optimal stopping policy gradient algorithm (OSPG) that leverages recurrent neural networks (RNNs) effectively in non-Markovian settings. This is achieved by implicitly optimizing value functions without recursion, which helps in mitigating the issue of the curse of non-Markovianity.
prediction: The authors propose a novel family of off-policy prediction algorithms that are convergent by construction. They propose to first learn on-policy about the data-generating behavior, and then bootstrap an off-policy value estimate on this policy, constructing a value estimate that is partially off-policy.

The authors propose a unified perspective to better understand policy optimization methods. This perspective re-expresses the underlying updates in terms of a limited choice of gradient form and scaling function, offering a parameterized space of approximate gradient updates for policy optimization.

The authors propose a novel approach called constraint-rectified policy optimization (CRPO) that operates differently from many popular SRL algorithms. CRPO alternates between improving objectives and satisfying constraints during policy updates.

This paper introduces the Optimistic variant of the Proximal Policy Optimization algorithm (OPPO), which follows an 'optimistic version' of the policy gradient direction, to address the issue of incorporating exploration in policy optimization.

The authors propose a novel policy optimization method called Constrained Update Projection (CUP), which provides rigorous safety guarantees. CUP is developed using newly proposed surrogate functions and performance bounds.

target: The paper expands upon previous works by designing new algorithms, along with lower bounds, to provide a comprehensive parameterized complexity picture for calculating Nash and individually stable outcomes, without necessarily restricting the number of colors to two.
prediction: The paper introduces a new equilibrium selection mechanism for a class of symmetric coordination games, which it asserts offers a natural solution that doesn't require players to guess.

log.reference: The paper introduces a new equilibrium selection mechanism for a class of symmetric coordination games, which it asserts offers a natural solution that doesn't require players to guess.
The authors investigate whether a player can achieve a utility surpassing that of the Stackelberg equilibrium when playing against a no-regret learner.

This study uses the theory of measure and linear algebra to investigate specific properties of the Nash equilibrium in 2-player finite simultaneous games. The authors seek to demonstrate the equality of the numbers of pure strategies assigned positive probability by the two players and the peculiar number of equilibria of the game (finite and odd) when all equilibria of the game are quasi-strong.

This paper identifies several natural classes of graphs where a finite improvement or coalition-improvement path of polynomial length always exists, allowing for a Nash equilibrium or strong equilibrium to be found in polynomial time.

The paper introduces the concept of a learning E-equilibrium for the resource selection game, which is a profile of algorithms, one designated for each player, where unilateral deviation by any player will not be beneficial to them irrespective of actual cost functions.

target: The paper introduces a novel approach called iFedCrowd (incentive-boosted Federated Crowdsourcing) which allows participants to locally process sensitive data, only uploading encrypted training models. This approach is designed to manage both the privacy and quality of crowdsourcing projects. An incentive mechanism is also introduced to encourage workers to constantly collect fresh data for training accurate client models and boosting global model training.
prediction: The authors introduce BLINDFL, a novel framework for VFL training and inference that can efficiently support various kinds of features and provides robust privacy guarantees.

log.reference: The authors introduce BLINDFL, a novel framework for VFL training and inference that can efficiently support various kinds of features and provides robust privacy guarantees.

They identify that good global performance does not translate to improved personalization and propose decomposing the network into a 'body' (extractor) and a 'head' (classifier) to address this issue.
The paper proposes PartialFed, a novel approach where instead of loading the entire model as in most previous works, only a subset of the global model’s parameters are loaded.

This paper presents FedX, an unsupervised federated learning framework that learns unbiased representation from decentralized and heterogeneous local data. It operates using a two-sided knowledge distillation approach with contrastive learning as a core component.

The authors propose a fair vertical federated learning framework (FairVFL) that learns unified and fair representations of data samples based on decentralized features in a privacy-preserving manner. The method involves local data representation learning and uses adversarial learning to remove bias inherited from the data.

target: The authors find that all Information Extraction tasks can be interpreted as extracting spans and span relations. They propose a Unified Token-pair Classification architecture for Information Extraction (UTC-IE) to unify all these tasks under the same token-pair classification formulation.
prediction: This study uses an iterative human-in-the-loop (HIL) framework that enables users to either write a regex or manually label entity mentions, then train a classifier based on this input. The authors propose OLEA, a new framework for ontology learning from text. This hybrid approach combines the pattern-based and the distributional methods to enhance recall and precision while addressing ontology evolution.

The authors present BioLiterate, a prototype software that uses natural language processing to extract entities, dependencies, and simple semantic relationships, which are then analyzed by a probabilistic reasoning module to form new relationships.

The authors describe the process of building a Web-scale entity search engine capable of handling over a billion Web pages, over 200,000 types, over 1,500,000 entities, and hundreds of entity annotations per page.
The authors propose a machine learning-based system, MetaSeer.STEM, developed to support automated extraction of data pertinent to STEM education meta-analyses.

target: A generate-and-edit approach is proposed which utilizes the execution results of the generated code from LLMs to improve the code quality on a competitive programming task, and a fault-aware code editor is used to correct errors in the generated code.

The authors propose a novel approach that dissects previous methods into a set of clearly defined, comparable subtasks, isolates the comparison of different approaches at each step of scientific workflow comparison, and explores how these can best be aggregated.
The authors propose a scenario-based diagnosis at a specification’s operator level using weak or strong fault models for specifications in Linear Temporal Logic (LTL).

The authors present two theorems about how the presence or absence of certain observations can assist in decomposing a diagnostic task into independent reasoning tasks or allow parts of a system to be ignored during diagnostic reasoning.

target: The authors introduce a flexible framework relying on stochastic frame-averaging (SFA) to make any model E(3)-equivariant or invariant through data transformations, and a new GNN named FAENet, optimized for SFA, that processes geometric information without any symmetry-preserving design constraints.

They also incorporate geometric and physical information in the message and update functions.

The authors propose a new methodology called cooperative neural networks (CoNN) that exploit the use of a cooperatively trained set of networks to capture latent representations by leveraging the given independence structure as a prior.
The authors propose a novel model that combines the benefits of previous work by incorporating the effects of latent features of objects and local structure in the network simultaneously.

The authors propose a novel backbone, Subequivariant Graph Neural Network, which considers external fields like gravity and relaxes equivariance to subequivariance, introduces an innovative subequivariant object-aware message passing system for learning physical interactions between variously shaped objects, and operates hierarchically to model long-range and complex interactions.

target: The paper proposes a new approach to generate substitute candidates from a paraphraser, owing to the paraphraser's ability to contain variations in word choice and preserve the sentence's meaning. Two simple decoding strategies that focus on variations of the target word during decoding are introduced.
prediction: This paper explores the novel idea of using bilingual parallel corpora as a source of lexical knowledge for cross-lingual textual entailment, claiming that phrase tables extracted from such data can capture both individual lexical relations and contextual information useful for inference.

log.reference: This paper explores the novel idea of using bilingual parallel corpora as a source of lexical knowledge for cross-lingual textual entailment, claiming that phrase tables extracted from such data can capture both individual lexical relations and contextual information useful for inference.

The authors propose a methodology for rare word bilingual extraction from comparable corpora using aligned comparable documents and supervised classification, incorporating a context-vector similarity and a co-occurrence model.
The authors propose an automatic method to extract paraphrases from definition sentences that are acquired from the Web, by regarding the sentences that define the same concept as parallel corpora.

The authors propose the use of document-level features, which capture necessary information from the context of the entire document from both target and source sides, to improve word sense disambiguation in the translation process.

The author proposes to test the language universal constraint delineated by the ITG using paraphrase and textual entailment data, which are thought to provide closer tests of certain aspects of the hypothesis than bilingual parallel corpora.

target: The authors propose MolXPT, a unified language model of text and molecules pre-trained on SMILES sequences wrapped by text. The author proposes the need for more abstract work representations and introduces a new format: Work-Function X Variable Matrices.

The authors propose DPLink, a deep learning-based framework for linking user identities based on heterogeneous, incomplete, and noisy mobility data collected from different services. DPLink uses feature extractors (a location encoder and a trajectory encoder), a comparator, a multimodal embedding network, and a co-attention mechanism to overcome the challenges associated with this problem.
The authors propose an innovative way of learning matrix representations of objects and relationships to model symbolic relationships between both objects and relationships.
The authors propose defining similarities on higher order tuples, not just pairs, resulting in the formation of hypergraphs which permits modeling of non-translational motion.

target: The authors propose REsidual Attention Debiasing (READ), an end-to-end debiasing method specifically designed to mitigate unintended biases from attention in language understanding tasks.

The authors highlight the existence of bias in models trained on data from social media platforms like Instagram and propose a context-aware and model-agnostic debiasing strategy using reinforcement learning. This debiasing technique doesn't require extra resources or annotations other than a predefined set of sensitive triggers which are commonly used to identify instances of cyberbullying.

This paper studies the data annotation bias when data items are presented as batches for simultaneous judgment by workers, proposes a novel worker model to characterize the annotating behavior on data batches, and presents a debiasing technique to remove the annotation bias effects.
The authors introduce the concept of upstream bias mitigation (UBM) where bias mitigation occurs in an upstream model via fine-tuning before being used for downstream task fine-tuning.

The authors propose a statistical framework for modeling and detecting annotator's position bias in crowdsourced data. Their method seeks to control the false discovery rate (FDR) without having prior knowledge about the number of biased annotators present.

target: The authors recast controlled generation under distribution shift as an invariant learning problem, implying the most effective predictor should be invariant across different text environments.
prediction: The paper adapts TPOT-RL for a completely different domain, network packet routing, demonstrating its versatility.

log.reference: The paper adapts TPOT-RL for a completely different domain, network packet routing, demonstrating its versatility.
The authors introduce the Nonlinear Embedding Transform (NET) for unsupervised DA by combining domain alignment with similarity-based embedding.

The authors propose an approach that uses unsupervised data to bring the source and target distributions closer in a learned joint feature space, by creating a symbiotic relationship between the learned embedding and a generative adversarial network.

This paper introduces the recently proposed von Neumann conditional divergence to improve transferability across multiple domains. This divergence can quantify the functional dependence between features and response y, and thus capture discriminative information in y.
The authors propose using regularization to achieve domain generalizations by learning a regularizer that enables a model trained on one domain to perform well on another.

target: This paper introduces an observation-guided radiology report generation framework (ORGAN) which first creates an observation plan and then uses this plan along with the radiographs to generate the report. An observation graph and a tree reasoning mechanism are utilized to enhance the plan information by capturing the multi-formats of each observation.

The authors present an approach for joint learning of language and perception models for grounded attribute induction, combining classifiers for physical characteristics and a probabilistic categorial grammar-based language model for construction of compositional meaning representations.

The paper proposes an end-to-end paradigm containing three complementary modules which take chest X-ray images and clinical history document of patients as inputs to generate fluent and clinically accurate medical reports.
The authors present RadGraph, a dataset of entities and relations in full-text chest X-ray radiology reports, based on a novel information extraction schema designed to structure radiology reports.

The authors propose a novel framework that exploits the structure information between and within report sections for generating CXR imaging reports. This includes a two-stage strategy that explicitly models the relationship between Findings and Impression, and a novel cooperative multi-agent system that implicitly captures the imbalanced distribution between abnormality and normality.

target: The authors propose a syntax-guided text generation schema that generates the sequence guided by a constituency parse tree in a top-down direction, leading to a more natural language texts generation.

The authors argue that natural languages can’t be genuinely represented by traditional formal languages, and should instead be modeled as families of formal languages or as formal languages with indefinite vocabularies. The authors also propose that human languages use queues instead of stacks, leading to the idea of developing a hierarchy of Queue Grammars in contrast to Chomsky Grammars.

This study presents an approach to training a joint syntactic and semantic parser that combines syntactic training information from CCGbank with semantic training information from a knowledge base using distant supervision.

The paper introduces the idea of using syntactic features, specifically two types of parse substructures (horizontal slices of trees, and feature schemas from discriminative parse reranking), for native language identification, based on the concept of contrastive analysis.
The authors propose a Conceptual Dependency (CD), script-style solution for automatically processing these money transfer messages due to the very restricted nature of the banking domain.

target: The proposed system leverages language model representations using hand-crafted tag descriptors and explores how integrating the contextualized representations of tag descriptors with a language model can improve performance.

The authors propose GroupReduce, a new compression method for neural language models. It operates through vocabulary-partition based low-rank matrix approximation and leveraging the inherent frequency distribution of tokens.

The authors propose a one-line-code normalization method to rectify the mismatch caused by the heavy bias towards word frequencies in embeddings from pre-trained models, thereby improving the synergy of large-scale pre-trained models and prototypical neural networks.

The authors focus on comparing seven different contextualized word representations for their ability to recognize the difference of frames that the same verb invokes, and to estimate the number of frames that a verb can evoke.

The authors aim to overcome these limitations by presenting a method for global-likelihood optimization of a Markov random field language model that exploits long-range contexts in time, independent of the corpus size.

target: The paper presents the System of Ensembling Fine-tuning Models (SEFM) for the SemEval-2023 Task 10: Explainable Detection of Online Sexism. The authors hypothesize that gender in these languages goes beyond suffixes or word endings, and is dictated by the general sound patterns of the language instead.

This study proposes using literature as an indicator for exploring women's work activities. A hybrid system is presented for automatic annotation of vocational signals in 19th century Swedish prose fiction, which also assigns gender (male, female, or unknown) to the vocation words.

The authors propose computational methods to study word choice within a sociolinguistic lexical variable, testing for changes in attitudes towards sexuality and gender in the United States by examining two variables: references to significant others and the indefinite person, both of which can be marked by gender.

The study uses a fine-grained approach to examine gender in the field of Natural Language Processing, utilizing topic models (Latent Dirichlet Allocation) to explore the research topics of men and women in the ACL Anthology Network.

target: This paper proposes a system to achieve high generalization in sentiment analysis by further pre-training of the AfroXLM Pre-trained Language Model (PLM), combining AfroXLM and MARBERT PLMs using a residual layer, and studying the impact of metric learning and two out-of-distribution generalization training objectives.
