The paper introduces MNID (Multiple Novel Intent Detection), a cluster-based framework designed to detect multiple new intents with a limited budget for human annotation.

The paper proposes ERNIE-M, a training method that relies on monolingual corpora to align the representation of multiple languages, breaking the constraint of parallel corpus size. It integrates the idea of back translation to generate pseudo-parallel sentences pairs, enhancing the semantic modelling of cross-lingual models.
The paper introduces a new General Language Model (GLM) that employs autoregressive blank infilling to improve performance across different tasks.

The authors propose a solution to mitigate the vulnerability of NLP models by applying random perturbations like spelling correction, synonym substitution, or dropping words at random places in the sentences.

target: The authors propose a conceptual design of a task-based, user-adaptive dashboard for an intelligent language tutoring system that not only displays the learning progress and performance, but also supports navigation through the learning content.
prediction: This study investigates the functionality of a web application called Critical Thinker, which is designed to allow learners to collaboratively develop structured arguments in a synchronous workspace with collaborative affordances.

log.reference: This study investigates the functionality of a web application called Critical Thinker, which is designed to allow learners to collaboratively develop structured arguments in a synchronous workspace with collaborative affordances.

The authors propose MixT, a system that generates mixed media tutorials that combine the advantages of both static step-by-step and video tutorials. MixT provides step-by-step text descriptions with images that are easily scanable, and short videos for each step that provide additional context and detail.

The authors introduce CourseMIRROR, a mobile system that prompts students' self-reflection and provides in-situ feedback to improve interactions. This system uses automatic text summarization techniques to aggregate student feedback and present the most significant ones to both instructors and students.

The researchers developed CourseMIRROR, an application that uses a mobile interface to administer prompts and collect reflective responses for instructor-assigned course lectures, and automatically summarizes the reflections with an extractive phrase summarization method.

The paper proposes a smart constructivist learning environment, which provides students with real-world problems collected from crowd-sourcing problem-solution exchange platforms, and assists students in problem-solving by retrieving relevant information on the Internet and auto-generating pertinent questions.

target: The authors suggest a different pre-training method called Masked Latent Semantic Modeling (MLSM), which shifts the objective from reconstructing the exact masked subwords to predicting their latent semantic characteristics.
prediction: The authors propose a Pre-trained masked Language mOdel with Misspelled knowledgE (PLOME) for CSC, which uses a learning technique to understand language and correct spelling errors. Instead of using a fixed token '[MASK]' as in BERT, PLOME masks chosen tokens with similar characters according to a confusion set.

log.reference: The authors propose a Pre-trained masked Language mOdel with Misspelled knowledgE (PLOME) for CSC, which uses a learning technique to understand language and correct spelling errors. Instead of using a fixed token '[MASK]' as in BERT, PLOME masks chosen tokens with similar characters according to a confusion set.

The authors propose a new generation task called 'faithfully reflecting updated information in text' (FRUIT), which aims to update an existing article given new evidence. They introduce the EDIT5, a T5-based method specifically designed for editing.

We point out the issues with existing bias evaluation metrics for MLMs and propose two new evaluation measures: All Unmasked Likelihood (AUL) and AUL with Attention weights (AULA) to predict all tokens in a test case given the MLM embedding of the unmasked input and evaluate the tokens based on their importance in a sentence, respectively.

The authors propose Masked Label Smoothing (MLS), a new mechanism that masks the soft label probability of source-side words to zero in order to better integrate label smoothing and vocabulary sharing in neural machine translation models.

This paper proposes to estimate the complexity of restoring original sentences from corrupted ones in language model pre-training. This entails consideration of the corruption degree in the ennoising process and the prediction confidence in the denoising process.

target: The authors explore five different parameter-efficient weight ensembling methods to achieve transferability between tasks. These methods leverage information from datasets and trained lightweight parameters to determine task similarity, then use comparability weighting to adapt parameters for new task initializations.
prediction: The authors develop two practical classification algorithms that robustly estimate posterior distributions from positive-unlabeled data -- these algorithms explicitly model noise in positive labels and utilize univariate transforms built on discriminative classifiers.

log.reference: The authors develop two practical classification algorithms that robustly estimate posterior distributions from positive-unlabeled data -- these algorithms explicitly model noise in positive labels and utilize univariate transforms built on discriminative classifiers.

The authors propose a new method which aims to reduce the volume of the version space more than half, going beyond existing methods. This approach introduces a sampling criterion of misclassification and a strong classifier, a modified DECORATE ensemble learning method, enhanced by the unlabeled instances with high certainty by the current base classifier.

The paper proposes to combine recent advancements in data filtering with the original analysis of Khayrallah and Koehn (2018) to evaluate whether state-of-the-art filtering systems can effectively remove all suggested noise types.

The authors introduce a fast, nonparametric algorithm for estimating class proportions. This method employs a unique sampling strategy that involves iterative drawing of positives, recording of minimum distances to unlabeled examples, and removal of nearest unlabeled space.

The authors propose a selection of filtering techniques to handle the issue of noise in LBD systems, two of which leverage the LBD system itself rather than relying on statistical or manual examination of document collections.

target: The paper explores for the first time whether the beneficial aspect of in-context instruction learning can be extended to a setting where tasks are sequentially fed to the target PLM for lifelong in-context instruction learning aimed at improving the target PLM's instance- and task-level generalization performance as it observes more tasks.
prediction: The authors propose a lifelong learning framework for neural topic modeling that processes streams of document collections, accumulates topics, and guides future topic modeling tasks with knowledge transfer from various sources, thus addressing data sparsity.

log.reference: The authors propose a lifelong learning framework for neural topic modeling that processes streams of document collections, accumulates topics, and guides future topic modeling tasks with knowledge transfer from various sources, thus addressing data sparsity.

The authors propose the application of few-shot learning in drug discovery, and suggest using explicitly graph-structured data to drive progress, supported by their introduction of a new few-shot learning dataset (FS-Mol) and a complementary benchmarking procedure.

The authors present a self-supervised pre-training pipeline that enables SATNet to overcome the Symbol Grounding problem, thus allowing SATNet to solve problems where no intermediary labels are available at all.
A representation-based evaluation framework is proposed that gives better understanding into representational forgetting within the learning process.

The key idea behind the author's dissertation is to focus on the representations used in lifelong learning systems. These representations should enable predictions and knowledge sharing over time, leading to continuous learning and adaptation in changing environments.

target: This study proposes a novel way to interpret neural networks through a linear decomposition method, considering the ReLU-activated Transformer as a linear model on a single input.
prediction: The authors propose to resurrect sigmoid in deep learning by achieving dynamical isometry through orthogonal weight initialization in deep nonlinear networks, countering the prevalent use of ReLU networks.

log.reference: The authors propose to resurrect sigmoid in deep learning by achieving dynamical isometry through orthogonal weight initialization in deep nonlinear networks, countering the prevalent use of ReLU networks.

The authors propose the idea of achieving successful deep learning with significantly fewer learnable parameters adapting to the target function, from an approximation perspective. They theorize that a ReLU network with a small number of intrinsic parameters can approximate any Lipschitz continuous function with an exponentially small error.

The authors propose a new approach called 'Analytic Marching', which uses the fact that a ReLU-based MLP creates linear regions in its input space. From these regions, the authors identify analytic cells and faces associated with the zero-level isosurface of the implicit function.
The authors propose the idea that there can be convergence to low robust training loss for neural networks of polynomial width under natural assumptions, using the ReLU activation function.

The authors propose to estimate the parameters of a single-layer ReLU network using a gradient descent algorithm combined with median- or trimmed mean-based filters to mitigate the effect of the arbitrary outliers.

target: The authors propose the versatile safe RL problem formulation incorporating two primary requirements: training efficiency and zero-shot adaptation capability. They introduce the Conditioned Constrained Policy Optimization (CCPO) framework consisting of two modules, the Versatile Value Estimation (VVE) and the Conditioned Variational Inference (CVI).
prediction: The paper presents a new algorithm for predicting the performance of a reinforcement learning policy from historical data more accurately and efficiently by introducing key advances including an extension of the doubly robust estimator and a new method to mix model-based and importance sampling-based estimates.

log.reference: The paper presents a new algorithm for predicting the performance of a reinforcement learning policy from historical data more accurately and efficiently by introducing key advances including an extension of the doubly robust estimator and a new method to mix model-based and importance sampling-based estimates.

The authors address the issue of objective mismatch in existing offline MBRL algorithms by developing a unique iterative framework, which seeks to maximize a lower bound of the true expected return by alternating between model training and policy learning.

The authors propose a bi-objective formulation for offline RL, named as 'Pareto policy pool (P3)', that aims to create a set of diverse policies offering varying levels of trade-offs, negating the need to carefully balance the trade-off between model return and uncertainty.

The authors propose the use of the determinant of a positive semidefinite matrix to approximate the action-value function in reinforcement learning, learning this matrix in such a way to represent both the relevance and diversity of actions.

The authors propose a model-free and off-policy trading strategy using Q-learning and state aggregation. This strategy can be implemented using a simple lookup table, and is designed to maximize net profit while constraining risk.

target: In this work, the authors introduce a theoretical framework for analyzing the effectiveness of using generative models in optimizing combinatorial problems. The models should be expressive enough to generate approximately optimal solutions, have a tractable number of parameters, and their optimization landscape should not contain sub-optimal stationary points.
prediction: The authors propose using machine learning to identify suitable subproblems within standard combinatorial optimization processes, replacing the traditional heuristic rules.

log.reference: The authors propose using machine learning to identify suitable subproblems within standard combinatorial optimization processes, replacing the traditional heuristic rules.
ML4CO competition aims to improve the state of combinatorial optimization by incorporating machine learning techniques into key heuristic components.
This paper proposes that systematic and local search techniques can exploit the hierarchical decomposition of space, preserved by spatial data structures, to efficiently guide search.
A decomposition of the Jump Point Search algorithm is proposed in this paper, allowing for the identification and understanding of its component pieces.

The paper proposes a novel method of nogood recording, where no-goods are recorded when the current cutoff value is reached, thus before a search algorithm restarts. Such a set of nogoods is taken from the last branch of the current search tree.

target: This study proposes a method for reconstructing complex images with high resolutions and large batch sizes in federated learning systems by constructing an over-parameterized convolutional network, allowing images to be generated before fitting to the gradient matching requirement.
prediction: A new approach to image downscaling and upscaling is proposed, envisioning these as an invertible bijective transformation. This forms the basis for the development of an Invertible Rescaling Net (IRN) which aims to produce visually pleasing low-resolution images and capture the distribution of the lost information using a latent variable following a specified distribution in the downscaling process.

log.reference: A new approach to image downscaling and upscaling is proposed, envisioning these as an invertible bijective transformation. This forms the basis for the development of an Invertible Rescaling Net (IRN) which aims to produce visually pleasing low-resolution images and capture the distribution of the lost information using a latent variable following a specified distribution in the downscaling process.

The authors present a new Demoireing network, C3Net, that is attentive in channel, color, and concatenation using residual blocks attentive in RGB channels and introducing a L1 color loss to combat color-striped pattern-caused moire patterns.
The authors propose a learning-based framework that treats light field acquisition as an auto-encoder problem, implemented as a stack of fully convolutional layers and trained end-to-end.

The authors propose a novel method based on Convolutional Neural Networks for content-preserving tone adjustment that decouples parameters' inference and color transformation, performing the former on a downsampled version of the input image, and the latter on the full resolution input.

This study proposes a learnable model called dynamic interpolation. It is constructed with a lightweight neural network to dynamically learn weights for interpolating neighboring pixels from input views to synthesize each pixel of novel views independently. As opposed to fixed and content-independent weights used in geometry warping, the proposed learned interpolation weights implicitly incorporate the correspondences between the source and novel views and adapt to different image content information.

target: The authors propose the Adversarial Visual Information Hiding (AVIH) method, which generates obfuscating adversarial perturbations to obscure visual data's visual information while ensuring hidden objectives are correctly predicted by models. Importantly, this method does not alter the parameters of the applied model, thereby ensuring its applicability in various scenarios.
prediction: The authors propose Longitudinal AdVersarial Attack (), a saliency score based adversarial example that requires a minimal amount of perturbations and can minimize the likelihood of being detected. This method selects and modifies features by using a joined saliency map and attention mechanism.

log.reference: The authors propose Longitudinal AdVersarial Attack (), a saliency score based adversarial example that requires a minimal amount of perturbations and can minimize the likelihood of being detected. This method selects and modifies features by using a joined saliency map and attention mechanism.

The authors propose a simple adversarial augmentation method to modify training data to be hard positives/negatives without distorting key identity information. This is achieved by decomposing a sample into its VAE reconstruction and the residual, perturbing the reconstruction in the VAE's bottleneck space, and then adding it back to the original residual as an augmentation.

The authors discover that images contain intrinsic structure that enables the reversal of many adversarial attacks; modifying the attacked image to restore the natural structure can serve as a defense against these adversarial threats.

The authors propose the first robust superpixel-guided attentional adversarial attack method. The adversarial perturbations are only added to the salient regions and are ensured to be the same within each superpixel.
The authors propose a novel bi-level optimization algorithm that robustifies images to adversarial perturbations by finding points within the vicinity of natural images.

target: A novel framework named 'Reflexion' is proposed that reinforces language agents not by updating weights, but through linguistic feedback, with agents verbally reflecting on task feedback signals, and maintaining their own reflective text in an episodic memory buffer to induce better decision-making in subsequent trials.
prediction: The authors study a setting where two agents play a referential game and, from scratch, develop a communication protocol necessary to succeed in this game. The communication protocol uses messages in the form of a language, i.e., sequences of discrete symbols.

log.reference: The authors study a setting where two agents play a referential game and, from scratch, develop a communication protocol necessary to succeed in this game. The communication protocol uses messages in the form of a language, i.e., sequences of discrete symbols.

The authors propose a framework for language learning that relies on multi-agent communication, where agents develop their own language interactively out of the need to communicate in the context of referential games.

The author focuses on the domain of human routines where behaviors are modeled as sequences of actions performed in specific situations. These computational models of routines are leveraged with different visualization tools to aid in understanding human behavior.

The authors present a novel approach which models routine behaviors as a series of frequent actions performed in specific situations. Instead of labelling each behavior instance, they weakly label instances using people's demonstrated routine and classify and generate new instances based on the probability that they belong to the routine model.

The successor to PLANES, named JETS, has been designed to provide an enhanced architecture for better conceptual coverage and to meet user requirements for conversation and database usage. It is also designed for higher degree of closure over concept manipulation for solving the problems of perspicuity and scale.

target: This paper introduces a robust and stealthy backdoor attack design: BITE. BITE poisons training data to establish strong correlations between a target label and certain 'trigger words' by naturally and iteratively injecting them into target-label instances.
prediction: A stronger weight-poisoning attack method is proposed. This method introduces a layerwise weight poisoning strategy to plant deeper undetectable backdoors with a combinatorial trigger.

log.reference: A stronger weight-poisoning attack method is proposed. This method introduces a layerwise weight poisoning strategy to plant deeper undetectable backdoors with a combinatorial trigger.
The paper proposes a novel approach, TDSSA (Truth Discovery against Strategic Sybil Attack), to defend against strategic Sybil attacks that attempt to evade traditional detection methods.
The authors develop a new data poisoning attack that allows an adversary to control model predictions whenever a desired trigger phrase is present in the input.

The authors propose a scheme to detect and mitigate sample-targeted backdoor attacks. They discover and demonstrate a unique property of the sample-targeted backdoor, which forces a boundary change such that small 'pockets' are formed around the target sample and propose a defense mechanism to pinpoint a malicious pocket by 'wrapping' them into a tight convex hull in the feature space.

The paper introduces a new neural backdoor attack, named 'Hibernated Backdoor', which remains in an inactive state to avoid detection until it's deployed and fine-tuned on end devices, where it becomes active and exploitable. This is achieved by maximizing the mutual information (MI) between the gradients of regular and malicious data on the model.

target: The authors propose a new approach, Unified Autonomous Driving (UniAD), a comprehensive framework that includes all full-stack driving tasks within one network. Instead of treating tasks separately, all tasks are designed to contribute specifically to planning, the ultimate goal of autonomous driving.
prediction: The authors propose an unsupervised real-to-virtual domain unification framework for end-to-end autonomous driving, called DU-drive. This framework transforms real driving data into a simpler virtual domain and then predicts vehicle control commands from this domain.

log.reference: The authors propose an unsupervised real-to-virtual domain unification framework for end-to-end autonomous driving, called DU-drive. This framework transforms real driving data into a simpler virtual domain and then predicts vehicle control commands from this domain.

The authors propose a new approach that learns vehicle control with the help of human advice by having the system learn to summarize its visual observations in natural language, predict an appropriate action response, and predict the controls accordingly. They also introduce a fine-grained attention mechanism based on semantic segmentation and object-centric RoI pooling to enhance interpretability.

A simulation framework called 'pseudoreality' is proposed, which can test an entire autonomous driving system, inclusive of deep-learning algorithms, dynamics models, and a near-photo-realistic rendering engine. Alongside this, the authors present a 'risk-based framework' for evaluating the probability of accidents under standard traffic conditions.

The author suggests a need for autonomous vehicles to infer various properties of dynamic objects based on their motion pattern. This includes the determination of whether an obstacle requires serious actions such as emergency stops or whether lower-key responses would suffice for less dangerous obstacles.

This paper proposes a new approach to introspective explanations for self-driving vehicles by using a visual attention model to train a convolutional network from images to vehicle control commands, and an attention-based video-to-text model to generate textual explanations. The attention maps of controller and explanation model are aligned so explanations are grounded in the parts of the scene that mattered to the controller.

target: This study is concerned with evaluating PLMs in the medical domain, with specific reference to the French language. The authors make the first comparison of performance of PLMs trained on both public data from the web and private data from healthcare establishments in French medical domain.
prediction: This study investigates how PLMs generate correct results through a causal-inspired analysis that measures and evaluates word-level patterns that PLMs rely on to generate missing words. The authors analyze words that have three typical associations with missing words: knowledge-dependent, positionally close, and highly co-occurred.

log.reference: This study investigates how PLMs generate correct results through a causal-inspired analysis that measures and evaluates word-level patterns that PLMs rely on to generate missing words. The authors analyze words that have three typical associations with missing words: knowledge-dependent, positionally close, and highly co-occurred.

This paper introduces TuringBench, a benchmark environment for the Turing Test in the age of neural text generation. The benchmark comprises a dataset with 200K human or machine-generated samples across 20 labels, two benchmark tasks - the Turing Test (TT) and Authorship Attribution (AA), and a leaderboard.
The authors introduce a benchmark dataset, Geo-Diverse Commonsense Multilingual Language Models Analysis (GeoMLAMA), to probe the diversity of relational knowledge in multilingual PLMs.

The authors present a general approach for vertical search based on domain-specific pretraining, specifically focusing on the biomedical domain, without using any explicit relevance labels for training or development.

This paper addresses the unresolved question of whether, where, and how PLMs encode sociodemographic aspects of language, through probing the sociodemographic knowledge of different single-GPU PLMs on multiple English data sets using traditional classifier probing and information-theoretic minimum description length probing.

target: SemEval-2023 Task 2 is a fine-grained multilingual NER task, calling for methods to identify complex fine-grained named entities in 12 languages, in both monolingual and multilingual scenarios, as well as noisy settings, using the MultiCoNER V2 dataset.
prediction: This paper introduces the SemEval-2010 task on Coreference Resolution in Multiple Languages, formulated to assess coreference resolution systems in six different languages using four different metrics over four evaluation settings.

log.reference: This paper introduces the SemEval-2010 task on Coreference Resolution in Multiple Languages, formulated to assess coreference resolution systems in six different languages using four different metrics over four evaluation settings.

The authors define a probabilistic representation for the meanings of words and describe a method for recovering meanings from observational information about word use in the face of referential uncertainty.

The authors present a co-clustering framework that can be used to discover multiple semantic and visual senses of a noun phrase, adopting a one-to-many mapping between text-based feature space and visual space.
The paper introduces a new task and a sequence tagging model that jointly infers lexical expressions and their supersenses in running text.

The authors propose an unsupervised technique for identifying solution posts by leveraging an unexplored textual feature, which is the lexical correlations between problems and solutions. The approach relies less on post metadata and employs translation models, language models, and an EM-formulation-based iterative solution identification approach.

target: The authors propose representing the optimal pruning decision as an equality-constrained 0-1 Integer Linear Programming problem and propose a self-regularization scheme where model prediction is regularized by the latest checkpoint with increasing sparsity throughout pruning.
prediction: The authors propose Differentiable Sparsity Allocation (DSA), an end-to-end budgeted pruning flow that employs a differentiable pruning process to determine layer-wise pruning ratios via gradient-based optimization.

log.reference: The authors propose Differentiable Sparsity Allocation (DSA), an end-to-end budgeted pruning flow that employs a differentiable pruning process to determine layer-wise pruning ratios via gradient-based optimization.

The authors propose a novel framework that allows for training a DNN only once, which can then be pruned to any sparsity ratio while preserving competitive accuracy without re-training, by re-casting DNN training as an explicit pruning-aware process formulated with an auxiliary K-sparse polytope constraint.

A novel method, TETRIS, is proposed to effectively handle the irregularity in pruned networks and achieve both better hardware utilization and higher sparsity. This is achieved by clustering the irregularly distributed weights into structured blocks via reordering the input/output dimension, and then structurally pruning them.

To improve the efficiency of network pruning, the authors propose entropy-based pruning, a new regularizer that can be integrated into existing network pruning algorithms. This approach, based on the insight that reducing the information entropy of the network outputs decreases the upper bound of the subsequent decoding search space, could address the slowdown caused by conventional pruning methods.
The paper intends to investigate the usefulness of Deep Neural Network (DNN) algorithms to alleviate the sparsity problem in CAVR, which is a relatively unexplored area.

target: The authors propose a new annotated dataset with human-labelled explanations and classification of Interpersonal Risk Factors (IRF) affecting mental disturbance on social media, namely Thwarted Belongingness (TBe) and Perceived Burdensomeness (PBu).
prediction: The authors investigate the language of Reddit posts specific to mental health to define linguistic characteristics that could be helpful for further applications, including identifying posts that need urgent attention.

log.reference: The authors investigate the language of Reddit posts specific to mental health to define linguistic characteristics that could be helpful for further applications, including identifying posts that need urgent attention.

The authors analyzed a large dataset from Reddit to understand how users progress between subreddits until expressing active suicidal ideation, as well as their posting patterns before and after expressing suicidal ideation.

This paper explores the role of expertise in responses provided to help-seeking posts regarding mental health with a focus on the differences between interactions with peers and interactions with self-identified mental health professionals. The fundamental distinction is measured through a classification model focusing on language use, engagement aspects, and linguistic style.
The authors propose a system for producing a disaster evacuation manual that includes accessible, versatile materials designed to cater to a wide range of needs and various disaster situations.

This paper discusses the EU FP7 project SUPER (Social sensors for secUrity assessments and Proactive EmeRgencies management), initiated in 2014, which aims to bridge the gap in technology for leveraging social media as sensors for security and emergency management.

target: The study examines and compares the learning trajectories of deep language models, specifically GPT-2, to those of children. The aim is to determine whether stages of language acquisition in GPT-2 during training are comparable to those observed in children aged 18 months to 6 years.
prediction: The authors propose a new framework, General Memory Augmented Pre-trained Language Model (G-MAP), which augments the domain-specific PLM with a memory representation from the frozen general PLM. This is achieved through a new memory-augmented layer and various strategies to build the memory representation and adaptively fuse it into the domain-specific PLM.

log.reference: The authors propose a new framework, General Memory Augmented Pre-trained Language Model (G-MAP), which augments the domain-specific PLM with a memory representation from the frozen general PLM. This is achieved through a new memory-augmented layer and various strategies to build the memory representation and adaptively fuse it into the domain-specific PLM.

The authors propose that scaling up language models greatly improves task-agnostic, few-shot performance. They present GPT-3, an autoregressive language model with 175 billion parameters, and test its few-shot learning capacity, without any gradient updates or fine-tuning.

The authors propose an ensemble setup composed of GPT-2 and ground-truth graphs from one of seven different formalisms, aiming to determine whether the incorporation of graph information can enhance perplexity and other metrics, thereby improving language modelling.

The authors propose AEDA (An Easier Data Augmentation), a new approach that involves only random insertion of punctuation marks into the original text, which is easier to implement than EDA and keeps the original order of words, thus preserving all input information.

The authors discuss the power of pre-trained language models (PLMs) using Transformer-based neural models, which learn universal language representations and outperform previous task-specific models given that they just need to be fine-tuned on the target corpus instead of being trained from scratch.

target: The paper proposes using a probing technique to elicit relational semantic knowledge from large-scale pre-trained language models. It also introduces a graph decomposition method to decompose the probing graph into four sub-graphs from intra- and inter-passage perspectives.
prediction: The authors introduce Cross Domain Zero Shot Named Entity Recognition with Knowledge Graph (DOZEN), a new approach to NER that leverages relations between entities across different domains from a chosen ontology and a set of conceptual links.

log.reference: The authors introduce Cross Domain Zero Shot Named Entity Recognition with Knowledge Graph (DOZEN), a new approach to NER that leverages relations between entities across different domains from a chosen ontology and a set of conceptual links.

This paper proposes the Read-Attend-Exclude (RAE) model, which aims to effectively comprehend the context and select the correct answer from different perspectives through a multi-round reasoning process, emulating human readers for MCRC.
The authors propose a system that learns low-dimensional embeddings of words and knowledge base constituents to score natural language questions against candidate answers.

The authors propose a two-stage method, Entailment Graph with Textual Entailment and Transitivity (EGT2), which learns local entailment relations by recognizing possible textual entailment between template sentences formed by typed CCG-parsed predicates.

The study proposes a novel one-stage end-to-end framework called Entailment Fused-T5 (EFT) aiming to bridge the information gap between decision-making and generation in a globally understanding manner.

target: The authors propose using DeBERTaV3 models and introduce an approach that takes into account the information-placement described within the webpages markup for classifying spoiler types in clickbait web articles.
prediction: The authors introduce and study the task of clickbait spoiling, a process of generating a short informative text that satisfies the curiosity aroused by a clickbait post. They propose approaches to classify the type of spoiler needed (a passage or a phrase) and to generate appropriate spoilers.

log.reference: The authors introduce and study the task of clickbait spoiling, a process of generating a short informative text that satisfies the curiosity aroused by a clickbait post. They propose approaches to classify the type of spoiler needed (a passage or a phrase) and to generate appropriate spoilers.

The paper presents a machine learning model to detect clickbait articles. The authors propose that the degree of informality of a webpage is a strong indicator of it being a clickbait, which is a novel feature in the model.

This study explores a new proxy-caching framework that capitalizes on the query semantics of HTML forms and introduces form-based proxy caching. It also introduces two caching schemes: (i) traditional passive query caching, and (ii) active query caching where the proxy cache services a request by evaluating a query over the cache contents.

This paper presents a new proxy caching framework that leverages the query semantics of HTML forms and identifies two common classes of form-based queries: keyword-based queries and function-embedded queries. The authors propose two caching schemes: passive query caching and active query caching where the proxy can answer a request by running a query over the cache content.

This paper presents techniques and a tool for semi-automated identification and resolution of mismatches between service interfaces and protocols, and for generating adapter specifications. It focuses on finding mismatches of type of signature, merge/split, and extra/missing messages, and also identifies all ordering mismatches between service protocols by generating a mismatch tree.

target: The authors conduct a comparison of pre-trained encoder-only and decoder-only language models with continued pre-training for detecting online sexism and put a focus on enhancing the interpretability of such systems.
prediction: The authors propose a multi-relational hyperbolic graph neural network-based approach, named Multi-relational Hyperbolic Diagnosis Predictor (MHDP), to build a more accurate disease predictive model.

log.reference: The authors propose a multi-relational hyperbolic graph neural network-based approach, named Multi-relational Hyperbolic Diagnosis Predictor (MHDP), to build a more accurate disease predictive model.

In this research, the authors propose a new evaluation method that uses the gender-sensitive corpus MuST-SHE and enriches it with two new linguistic annotation layers (parts-of-speech and agreement chains), to explore how different lexical categories and agreement phenomena are impacted by gender skews.
The authors have developed the first interactive virtual environment, VEGA, to allow users to explore and compare machine translation services regarding gender bias and their accuracy.
The authors hypothesize that gender in these languages goes beyond suffixes or word endings, and is dictated by the general sound patterns of the language instead.

This paper proposes a Multi-modal Clinical Data based Hierarchical Multi-label model (MHM) that integrates discrete medical codes, structural information, and time series data into a unified framework for the diagnosis prediction task.

target: The authors propose a model using the LinkBERT transformer in the biomedical domain, denoted as BioLinkBERT. The model uses sentences from clinical trial reports as evidence in premise-statement inference to determine inference relations, and applies a soft voting ensemble mechanism to enhance system performance.
prediction: This study explores the use of large transformer models, specifically T5 and GPT-3, for machine-paraphrase generation on various types of texts including scientific articles, student theses, and Wikipedia entries. Additionally, it investigates the performance of automated solutions and commercial software in detecting these paraphrases.

log.reference: This study explores the use of large transformer models, specifically T5 and GPT-3, for machine-paraphrase generation on various types of texts including scientific articles, student theses, and Wikipedia entries. Additionally, it investigates the performance of automated solutions and commercial software in detecting these paraphrases.

The authors present TaBERT, a pretrained language model that is designed to jointly learn representations for natural language sentences and structured tables, trained using a large corpus of tables and their English contexts.

This paper proposes EventBERT, a pre-trained model that encapsulates eventuality knowledge from unlabeled text. The model is pre-trained on a large volume of training examples identified in natural language paragraphs that describe multiple correlated events.

The authors propose SpaBERT, a novel spatial language model, that provides a general-purpose geo-entity representation based on neighboring entities in geospatial data. SpaBERT extends BERT to capture linearized spatial context, along with preserving spatial relations using a spatial coordinate embedding mechanism.

This study introduces the use of BERT, a deep contextualized language model, for the task of ad hoc table retrieval, focusing on encoding table content taking into account the table structure and input length limit of BERT.

target: The authors present an imitation learning approach where a teacher NMT system corrects the errors of an AST student without relying on manual transcripts.
prediction: The authors develop a phoneme-based Manipuri Keyword Spotting System (MKWSS) using Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM).

log.reference: The authors develop a phoneme-based Manipuri Keyword Spotting System (MKWSS) using Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM).

The authors propose several new approaches to the syllabification of phonemes, branching out from simply linguistic theories to include a discriminative learning technique that combines Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Hidden Markov Model (HMM) technologies.

The researchers propose the use of internet-sourced pronunciations and their impact on spoken term detection. They suggest techniques for efficiently extracting candidate pronunciations from web pages, associating these with orthographic words, and normalizing them to conform to commonly accepted transcription standards.

This paper revisits the problem of English word pronunciation using native phone sets and evaluates two methods: phone-phone substitution and word-phone mapping. However, unlike other works, it does not consider non-native language phone sets.

The authors propose an algorithmic framework for phoneme classification that uses a rooted tree to encode a predefined hierarchical structure of phonemes. The learning task is formulated as an optimization problem with margin constraints over the phoneme set.

target: The authors propose to rely on dynamic learning analytics for automatic and dynamic generation and adaptation of distractors in Single Choice exercises, as well as informing exercise generation in terms of relevant learning goals and reasonable chunking in Jumbled Sentences exercises.

The study presents the implementation and evaluation of a process that uses syntactic phrase structure trees from parser as input to generate cloze questions automatically.
The ASKNet project is an attempt to automatically generate semantic knowledge networks from natural language text by using NLP tools such as parsers and semantic analysers.

This paper presents a scheme to label question-answer pairs with medical terminologies by jointly using local mining and global learning approaches where the local mining independently extracts medical concepts from the QA pairs and the global learning enhances local mining by discovering missing terminologies and keeping off the irrelevant terms.

target: The authors propose a solution to the identified problem: a training algorithm called LM-TOAST, which makes PLMs both task-solvers and self-calibrators. This addresses the challenges of limited training samples, data imbalance, and distribution shifts.

This approach can learn from different schemas and inference datasets, allowing domain-specific schemas to be defined using natural language.

The authors identify and analyze the order sensitivity phenomenon in language models, which leads to performance variation. They also present a strategy to overcome this issue by using the generative nature of language models to construct an artificial development set and identify performant prompts based on entropy statistics of the candidate permutations.

target: The paper proposes a two-stage translation prototype called hybrid-regressive translation (HRT) that combines the robustness of AT with the speed of NAT by first generating discontinuous sequences via autoregression and then filling in all previously skipped tokens at once in a non-autoregressive manner.

A novel NAT framework namely ReorderNAT is proposed, which explicitly models the reordering information to guide the decoding process of non-autoregressive translation.
This paper introduces the LEAD framework which uses heterogeneous knowledge from dictionaries relating to phonetics, vision, and meaning, to improve CSC models.

target: The authors question the necessity of MP in KGC tasks, finding that simple MLP models can achieve comparable performance to MPNNs. They also highlight the impact of careful scoring function and loss function design on the KGC model's performance.

The authors propose a novel heterogeneous GNN architecture derived from optimization steps that descend a novel relation-aware energy function, wherein the minimizer of this function is fully differentiable to enable bilevel optimization for node representation learning.

The authors present a framework called 'learning to propagate'. This framework learns the GNN parameters for prediction and can explicitly learn the personalized propagation strategies for different nodes and various types of graphs.

The authors introduced the Deep network Dynamic Graph Partitioning (DDGP), a novel algorithm for optimizing graph division so that vertices in every subgraph have a similar distribution, hence improving the performance of expert models trained on these subgraphs.
The authors propose novel methods that extend GNN-based architectures to achieve value-set invariance, which allows these models to generalize across different sizes of the output space.

target: The paper introduces a novel fine-tuning method known as DEER that allows a single pre-trained model to perform Dynamic and Efficient infERence. prediction: To address these challenges the authors propose the AISLe model, which employs adversarial learning and importance sampling for precision and coverage, and a multimodal multiscale attention block for subword alignment without explicit alignment between language and acoustic cues.

This paper does not propose a new idea, but instead provides a thorough tutorial and review of non-autoregressive sequence generation, covering aspects including motivation, problem definition, evaluation protocol, model architecture, objective function, training data, learning paradigm, and additional inference tricks.

The authors propose Levenshtein Transformer, a partially autoregressive model that allows for more flexible and amenable sequence generation. Unlike previous models, this one is based on basic operations such as insertion and deletion, which not only enable generation but also refinement of sequences and dynamic length changes.

The paper proposes a streaming end-to-end framework capable of processing multiple intentions in an online and incremental manner. The framework consists of a unidirectional RNN trained with the connectionist temporal classification (CTC) criterion, allowing for identification of multiple sequential intentions.

This paper introduces a simple, model-agnostic multi-task learning framework that uses a set of weak AR decoders that rely solely on the information provided by the NAR decoder during training. This setup forces the NAR decoder to enhance its capabilities to support its weak AR partners.

target: The authors propose a fine-grained attention alignment approach that jointly optimizes a cascade document ranking model. The approach uses the attention activations from the document ranker as feedback to optimize the selector and fuses the relevance scores from the selector into the ranker.
prediction: The authors propose the use of deep learning techniques to learn effective mapping functions that capture both intramodal and intermodal semantic relationships of data from heterogeneous sources.

A computational framework is proposed which implements both types of modal and amodal completion and includes a fully automatic decision-making mechanism for selecting between them. It is capable of inferring descriptions in terms of overlapping layers and labelling junctions as T, L, and endpoints.

This paper proposes to utilize user actions as a source of weak supervision, along with a limited set of annotated examples, for the task of email intent detection. It introduces a novel, end-to-end deep neural network model that leverages both clean annotated data and noisy weak supervision along with a self-paced learning mechanism.

The authors propose a way of decomposing hidden states over a sequence into temporal and input-driven components to understand how attention matrices are formed and how they are utilized in different sequence-to-sequence tasks.

This study proposes a hybrid attention mechanism to model question-answer pairs and leveraging user information for answer selection. The model determines local importance (intra-sentence attention) and counterpart sentence importance (inter-sentence attention) for each word and utilizes answer data from users to bridge the semantic gap between different users.

target: The authors aim to answer the question raised by Zhang et al., regarding the capability of probabilistic generating circuits to efficiently represent all strongly Rayleigh distributions.
prediction: The authors argue that neither traditional approach is adequate for addressing the scaling problem, and they point to the need for efficient parallel knowledge discovery systems given the impracticality of some tasks with even polynomially complex algorithms.

The authors propose a new form of IDS, called Ignorant Influence Diagrams (iiDs), which can operate with incomplete information and improve decision accuracy as a function of the increasing availability of information.
This paper introduces linear space data structures to represent sets such that their intersection can be calculated quickly.
The study proposes an abstraction scheme, including concepts of abstract networks and abstract junction trees, aimed at simplifying Bayesian belief network structures for future inference sessions.
The paper introduces linear space data structures to represent sets, allowing their intersection to be computed in a worst-case efficient way.

target: The authors propose Dynamic Prompt Learning (DPL) to refine cross-attention maps which forces more attention on correct noun words in the text prompt. This addresses the issue of unintended changes in off-target areas during text-based image editing.

The authors propose a microscopic analysis based on an effective theory and a macroscopic analysis of phase diagrams for understanding grokking. They also identify four learning phases: comprehension, grokking, memorization, and confusion, with the grokking phase being crucial for continued generalization.

The authors propose an effective method for fine-tuning multiple downstream generation tasks simultaneously using a single, large pre-trained model, using only an additional 2-3% parameters for each task.
The authors propose a novel approach to generating answers from a set of AS2 top candidates by training a sequence to sequence transformer model instead of just selecting the best candidate.

The authors identify 'skill neurons' within pre-trained Transformers that have high predictive value for task labels after prompt tuning for specific tasks and establish their task-specificity and crucial role in task handling.

target: The authors propose a novel approach named DisCal to enhance the level of abstractiveness (measured by n-gram overlap) without sacrificing the informativeness (measured by ROUGE) of generated summaries. DisCal exposes diverse pseudo summaries with two supervision to the student model.
prediction: The authors introduce the novel problem of dynamic entity summarization for entity cards, which they subdivide into two specific tasks: fact ranking and summary generation.

log.reference: The authors introduce the novel problem of dynamic entity summarization for entity cards, which they subdivide into two specific tasks: fact ranking and summary generation.

The authors propose BanditSum, a novel method that treats extractive summarization as a contextual bandit problem, where the model receives a document to summarize and chooses a sequence of sentences to include in the summary. A policy gradient reinforcement learning algorithm is used to train the model.
The authors propose leveraging discourse structure to formulate a monotone (non-decreasing) sub-modular scoring function to generate more comprehensible summaries.

The study introduces a full-scale multimodal dataset for summarization that gathers documents, summaries, images, captions, videos, audios, transcripts, and titles in English from CNN and Daily Mail. A baseline model is also developed, which employs a newly proposed Jump-Attention mechanism based on transcripts.

The authors put forward an improved approach to extractive summarization featuring integrated random walk on a graph constructed based on topical/lexical relations. They also model intra-speaker topics by partially sharing topics from the same speaker in the graph.

target: A theoretical examination is conducted to comprehend chaotic and non-smooth optimizations in model-based RP PGMs. The smoothness of function approximators is identified as a major factor affecting gradient estimation quality in these situations.

The authors propose a parallel stochastic algorithm that neither requires explicit information on internal network structure, nor depends on the model. They propose a modified parameter update rule where each individual parameter vector perturbation contributes a decrease in error.

The authors propose to use stochastic coordinate descent on the orthogonal group to improve scalability of learning algorithms for orthogonal recurrent neural networks. The authors also propose a variant of their algorithm leveraging approximately sparse structure of the Riemannian gradient using the Gauss-Southwell coordinate selection rule.

The authors present a new analysis approach, using techniques based on optimal transport and the Sampled Gaussian Mechanism, to characterize the differential privacy of Stochastic Gradient Descent with noise for a large range of parameters.

The authors propose a stochastic procedure, the mirror descent, for constructing an aggregated estimator which performs gradient descent in the dual space. Generated estimates are additionally averaged in a recursive manner with specific weights.

target: The authors propose a decorrelation-enhanced GCF objective that promotes feature diversity by leveraging the principle of redundancy reduction in embeddings, using non-Euclidean geometry to maintain the range space of the matrix and obtain a small condition number, thereby preventing the embedding space degradation.

The authors propose a method named Local Learning Projection (LLP), a linear dimensionality reduction approach designed to minimize local estimation error instead of global.

The study proposes a new robust metric learning model that projects from a higher dimensional Grassmann manifold to a lower, more discriminative one. In this space, the errors between sample points are considered as a Maximum Likelihood Estimation-like estimator.

The authors propose a nonlinear discriminative dimensionality reduction method which represents the low-dimensional embedding as linear combinations of predefined smooth vectors with respect to data manifold. Optimal combination coefficients and optimal cluster assignment matrices are computed by simultaneously maximizing between-cluster scatter, minimizing within-cluster scatter, and preserving smoothness of the cluster assignment matrix.

The authors propose a novel approach called Local Intrinsic Dimension estimation using approximate Likelihood (LIDL) that relies on an arbitrary density estimation method, aiming to sidestep the challenges posed by high dimensionality, by leveraging recent progress in parametric neural methods for likelihood estimation.

target: The authors provide a systematic and in-depth analysis on OOD detection for document understanding models, studying the effects of model modality, pre-training, and fine-tuning across various types of OOD inputs. This paper proposes to overcome the issues in OOD detection by regarding the feature's high-probability region of the deep model as the feature's typical set. The key novelty is that each task is trained as an OOD detection model rather than a traditional supervised learning model, and a task mask is trained to prevent forgetting.

The authors approach the Out-Of-Distribution (OOD) recommendation problem in an OOD environment with user feature shifts from a causal view, formulating the user feature shift as an intervention and OOD recommendation as post-intervention inference of the interaction probability.

A new set of benchmarks and an approach, semantically coherent out-of-distribution detection (SC-OOD), is proposed that focuses on the inherent semantics of the data rather than the low-level discrepancies between data sources.

target: The paper proposes a workshop aiming to gather seasoned scholars and early career researchers to explore the intersection of generative AI and Human Computer Interaction (HCI). They will scrutinize the interaction of humans with generative AI, ethical controls, and collaborative patterns.

ATHack, an annual assistive technologies hackathon at MIT, addresses this gap by involving community members living with disabilities (co-designers) who propose projects and work with developers to create prototypes over two weeks.
This workshop proposes to explore the opportunities and implications of digital fabrication for HCI, focusing on five main themes.
This panel discussion focuses on the emergence and expansion of MTHD in HCI and human-centered design, which can be seen as a significant shift in the design paradigm.

The tutorial is intended to be an introduction to CIS, covering both basic and advanced topics. A significant part of the tutorial is hands-on experiences based on toolkits developed by the presenters.

target: This work presents GeneticFlow (GF), a suite of graph-based scholar profiles that fulfill three requirements: structured-context, scholar-centric, and evolution-rich. The authors propose a framework to compute GF over large-scale academic data sources.

This paper introduces a method, Shift-Robust GNN (SR-GNN), designed to account for distributional differences between biased training data and the graph's actual inference distribution.
The paper introduces Deep Graph Kernels, a framework that learns latent representations of graph sub-structures with the aim to exploit the dependency information between these sub-structures.

This paper proposes an efficient data augmentation strategy, called local augmentation, aimed at bolstering GNN's expressive power with generated features by learning the distribution of node representations of neighbors conditioned on the central node’s representation.

In response to this context, the authors propose 'Graph Model Inversion' (GraphMI), a novel technique to extract private graph data from GNNs. GraphMI is designed to tackle the discreteness of graph edges while preserving the sparsity and smoothness of graph features.

target: This study proposes to improve the RDW experience by mitigating visual-vestibular inconsistencies using four types of vestibular stimulations: noisy and directional galvanic vestibular stimulation, bone-conduction vibration, and caloric vestibular stimulation.

The authors propose novel algorithms that operate directly on WPDAs, which draw inspiration from Lang's algorithm, but use a more general definition of pushdown automaton.

The authors propose a probabilistic type inference scheme called LambdaNet for TypeScript based on a graph neural network. They use lightweight source code analysis to generate a program abstraction in the form of a type dependency graph.

To tackle existing challenges, a Probabilistic Grammar of Graphics (PGoG) is proposed, an extension to Wilkinson's original framework. The PGoG enables probability expressions to be a first-class citizen in the language, dichotomizes probability and frequency framing, and is capable of encompassing various visualization methods.
The paper introduces a recursive variant of the CYK+ algorithm that eliminates the use of the dot chart without increasing the time complexity for SCFG decoding.

The authors focused on the design challenge in a group memory to enable low-effort information sharing without reducing the individual's finding effectiveness. They also discussed the cognitive obstacles to a shared information structure.

The authors conducted a study to understand the trade-off between suggestion savings and interaction costs by controlling the assertiveness of an interface which is defined by the tendency for an interface to present itself.

This study focuses on analyzing the GitHub Sponsor mechanism and its impact on open source software development. The research examines why developers participate, how the mechanism impacts developer activity, who gets more sponsorships, and what flaws developers encounter using the mechanism.
The authors applied the method of using typical potential users to evaluate the user interface, where their efforts to complete a sample task were observed and videotaped.

target: This work seeks to address the limitations in scoring functions by employing the unbalanced optimal transport theory and hence investigating the local and global trade-off. The authors introduce a theoretical framework for statistical tasks using the Gromov-Wasserstein (GW) distance. This framework translates the GW Riemannian framework previously developed by Sturm into simple tools for network data analysis.

The authors propose deep Wasserstein graph discriminant learning (WGDL) for encoding discriminative embeddings of graphs in Wasserstein-metric matching space. A graph dictionary, which is a reference set of graphs, is introduced to overcome the challenges of calculating class centers and support batch process learning.

The study introduces Wasserstein Coupled Graph Learning (WCGL), a method for cross-modal retrieval. It specifically constructs graphs based on cross-modal samples, uses graph encoders for feature extraction, and builds a Wasserstein coupled dictionary for further feature learning.

The authors argue and demonstrate that no DR maps can achieve perfect precision and perfect recall simultaneously, implying that continuous DR maps must have imperfect precision. Moreover, they propose a new measure based on Wasserstein distance to evaluate `howu0027 wrong the retrieved data is.

target: This paper proposes a 5W framework (who, what, when, where, and why) for question-answer-based fact explainability and introduces the FACTIFY-5WQA dataset. The authors propose a framework for a visually grounded question-asking model that generates polar (yes-no) clarification questions to resolve misunderstandings in dialogue. This model is unique in that it does not need any supervised question-answer data, deriving informative questions from an off-the-shelf image captioner using an expected information gain objective.

The authors introduce a new PQA framework, Riker, which bridges the gap between interpretability and effectiveness in mapping questions to their relevant answers. Riker leverages two components - internal word re-weighting and external word association, to extract rich keyword representations from the questions.
The authors propose a knowledge-to-text transformation framework to benchmark knowledge-enhanced CQA and understand the extent of knowledge exploitation in current models.

A QA system, LogAnswer, is proposed for the German language, which combines methods from various fields of AI including natural language processing, machine learning, knowledge representation and automated theorem proving. The key contribution is a machine learning solution to the wrong answer avoidance (WAA) problem with meta classifiers applied to the outputs of term-based classifiers and other WAA features.

target: The authors propose taking a step back from the technical component and focus on how linguistic aspects such as mutual intelligibility or degree of language relatedness can improve ARA in a low-resource setting.

This method adjusts the joint distribution of source-target word pairs derived from OLD-domain data to match the marginal distributions of NEW-domain data, while minimizing the divergence from the OLD-domain distribution.

This study produces a parallel corpus of translated and simultaneously interpreted text and uses it to study the differences between the two, gaining insights into the tactics used by human interpreters to reduce translation latency.
The paper introduces a novel method to automatically acquire query translation pairs by mining web click-through data, eliminating the need for web crawling or Chinese word segmentation.

The authors propose a web-based bilingual tool, DOMCAT, that retrieves sentence pairs from a bilingual corpus, identifies translation equivalents of multi-word expressions as queries and ranks the retrieved sentence pairs in relevance to the query and its translation equivalents.

log.reference: The authors propose a framework to expose any biases used by code generation models by systematically removing hints from the coding challenges, to help understand how these models exploit specific prompt structures and keywords.

The authors propose a new approach to reduce gender disparity in text generation by learning a fair model during knowledge distillation, based on two modifications - modifying teacher probabilities and augmenting the training set.

The authors study the gender bias in meta-embeddings created under three different settings, and propose a novel debiasing method based on meta-embedding learning using multiple debiasing methods on a single source embedding to create an unbiased meta-embedding.

A demo is introduced that uses interactive visualization to increase the interpretability of state-of-the-art techniques for mitigating biases in word representations, particularly from a geometric perspective.

The authors propose a debiasing method for pre-trained text encoders that focuses on reducing social stereotypes without inflicting significant semantic damage. By examining the attention mechanism of these encoders, they find that stereotypes are also encoded in the attention layer.

target: The authors propose Diable, a new task formalisation for dialogue state tracking, which simplifies the design and implementation of DST systems. The authors propose the CodeRetriever model, which uses large-scale code-text contrastive pre-training to learn semantic representations of code at the function level. The model incorporates two types of contrastive learning - unimodal, building semantic-related code pairs based on documentation and function name, and bimodal, building code-text pairs from code's documentation and in-line comments.

The authors propose a Recursive Inference mechanism (ReInf) for DST in multi-domain scenarios. The mechanism reviews the dialogue history in reverse until it locates sufficient turns for slot value prediction, and also accounts for dependencies among domains and slots to resolve co-reference and value sharing issues.

The authors propose DiCoS-DST, a model that dynamically selects the relevant dialogue contents per slot for state updating. It evaluates turn-level utterances relevancy from three perspectives: connection to the slot name, relevance to current turn dialogue, and Implicit Mention Oriented Reasoning.

The authors propose to incorporate structure learning into the graph-based neural models for headline generation, aiming to automatically learn the sentence graph in a data-driven way, avoiding the need for pre-existing heuristics or rules.

target: This paper proposes Fine-Grained RLHF, a framework that leverages fine-grained human feedback, such as pinpointing where a sentence is false, and uses it as an explicit training signal. This feedback is fine-grained in two respects: density, providing a reward after every segment is generated, and incorporating multiple reward models associated with different feedback types.
prediction: This paper takes a new approach, proposing the idea of framing curricula as interpolations between task distributions, and reframing the generation of a Curriculum Reinforcement Learning curriculum as a constrained optimal transport problem.

log.reference: This paper takes a new approach, proposing the idea of framing curricula as interpolations between task distributions, and reframing the generation of a Curriculum Reinforcement Learning curriculum as a constrained optimal transport problem.

This approach allows for the generation and comprehension of backchannels and barge-ins by employing the psycholinguistic hypothesis of information density (ID).
The authors propose a new form of explanation for Reinforcement Learning, called 'intended outcome', which involves collecting information for explanations in conjunction with training the agent.

This paper introduces the concept of contingency awareness to reinforcement learning, exploring it in the context of Atari 2600 games. A technique for accurately identifying contingent regions and exploiting this knowledge to improve features for value function approximation is proposed.

This paper introduces RouLette, an intelligent engine for multi-query execution that overcomes the shortcomings of previous work-sharing strategies through runtime adaptation, using reinforcement learning to switch between exploration and exploitation of opportunities.

target: The paper introduces XLM-P, a system that contextually retrieves prompts as flexible guidance for encoding instances conditionally, enabling lightweight modeling of language-invariant and language-specific knowledge across languages and easy integration with other multilingual pre-training methods.
