The paper proposes a representation learning framework, the Relational Graph Transformer Network (RGTN), which leverages the wealth of information inherent in nodes and edges to improve NIE. This framework uses a relational graph transformer to propagate node information with consideration of semantic predicate representations, and employs two encoders to capture both the structural and semantic information of nodes.

This paper introduces the Graph of Graphs Neural Network (GoGNN) that extracts the features in structured entity graphs and the entity interaction graph hierarchically. A dual-attention mechanism is also proposed to preserve neighbor importance at both graph levels.

The authors propose to model inter-stock relations as a graph, treating stock selection as a scale-free graph-based learning to rank problem. They introduce HyperStockGAT, a Hyperbolic Stock Graph Attention Network, said to be the first model on the Riemannian Manifolds for stock selection.

The authors present a novel Multimodal Structure-evolving Continual Graph Learning (MSCGL) model which continually learns both the model architecture and the associated parameters for the Adaptive Multimodal Graph Neural Network (AdaMGNN). The MSCGL model takes into account social information and multimodal information to build multimodal graphs and continually adapts to new tasks without forgetting old ones.

target: This study examines the influence of the quality rather than the quantity of the training data on the generalization of a model, particularly focusing on two types of data: human-adversarial (h-adversarial), sample pairs with small differences but different ground-truth labels, and human-affable (h-affable), sample pairs with minor differences but the same ground-truth labels.

The paper proposes that adversarially-trained models transfer better than non-adversarially-trained models, especially when dealing with limited data for the new domain task.

This paper provides statistical insights into why artificially generated data improve adversarial training, including how the attack strength and quality of unlabeled data affect adversarial robustness. Additionally, an algorithm is proposed to perform an online adjustment to the weight between the labeled real data and the generated data.
The authors propose to use domain expertise to identify statistically predictive but legally irrelevant information and adopt adversarial training to prevent the system from relying on it.

The authors propose a new adversarial training approach for robustness over an unseen test domain that is not i.i.d. but deviates from the training domain. The model doesn't have access to data from the test domain but has a broad specification about the types of perturbations in terms of attributes.

target: The authors investigate the cross-over between the regimes of over-parametrized networks and narrow networks in a high-dimensional setting, especially the connection between the mean-field/hydrodynamic regime and Saad & Solla's approach.

The authors introduce a novel network type that uses unit-length 2-vectors for local variables, referred to as 'phasor' models.
The authors propose an exchangeable neural network for summary statistic-free, likelihood-free inference that can be applied across a variety of simulation-based tasks.

The authors propose a novel way of deriving new surrogates for stochastic neural networks by treating them as Markov chains. They also perform a theoretical study of these surrogates at initialization.

The authors establish an exact mapping between correlated pattern Hopfield networks and Restricted Boltzmann Machines, demonstrating that a HN with N binary variables and potentially correlated binary patterns can transform into an RBM with N binary visible variables and Gaussian-hidden variables.

target: The authors work on deriving exact solutions to the dynamics of learning with rich prior knowledge in deep linear networks by generalizing Fukumizu's matrix Riccati solution.

log.reference: The authors propose a combination of a nonlinear recurrent neural predictive model and a linear error model that makes prediction and maximum likelihood adaptation rules tractable.

The authors establish an exact mapping between correlated pattern Hopfield networks and Restricted Boltzmann Machines, demonstrating that a HN with N binary variables and potentially correlated binary patterns can transform into an RBM with N binary visible variables and Gaussian-hidden variables.

The authors propose a new concept of treating RNNs as discretizations of stochastic differential equations driven by input data, and they analyze the implicit regularization effect of general noise injection schemes in the context of this framework.
The authors introduce a novel network type that uses unit-length 2-vectors for local variables, referred to as 'phasor' models.
The authors propose a mean field approximation that captures in a fairly transparent manner the qualitative, and many of the quantitative, results of the network theory.

target: The paper introduces UniST, a Unified Style Transfer framework for both images and videos that includes a domain interaction transformer (DIT). This DIT explores context information within the specific domain first and then interacts contextualized domain information for joint learning. The DIT also enables exploration of temporal information from videos for the image style transfer task and allows rich appearance texture from images for video style transfer.
prediction: The authors propose the Style-HAllucinated Dual consistEncy learning (SHADE) framework, which is based on two consistency constraints, Style Consistency (SC) and Retrospection Consistency (RC), and includes a novel style hallucination module (SHM) to generate style-diversified samples that are crucial for consistency learning.

log.reference: The authors propose the Style-HAllucinated Dual consistEncy learning (SHADE) framework, which is based on two consistency constraints, Style Consistency (SC) and Retrospection Consistency (RC), and includes a novel style hallucination module (SHM) to generate style-diversified samples that are crucial for consistency learning.
This paper proposes that the sequential introduction of different loss functions into the learning process can improve the performance of a standard model for text style transfer.
The authors propose Content-Style Modulation (CoSMo), a new algorithm for designing an image-text compositor that focuses on yielding a representation similar to the target image.

The study introduces COCO-FUNIT, a new few-shot image translation model that computes the style embedding of example images conditioned on the input image and a new module named the constant style bias in order to address the content loss problem.

The authors propose a style-aware content loss mechanism, which is trained jointly with a deep encoder-decoder network, to provide real-time, high-resolution stylization of images and videos that better captures the subtle nuances of a given style.

target: The work proposes a byte-level traffic graph construction approach based on point-wise mutual information (PMI) and a model named Temporal Fusion Encoder using Graph Neural Networks (TFE-GNN) for feature extraction.
prediction: The authors propose a context aware graph convolutional network (CA-GCN). In addition to performing localized graph convolution, CA-GCN integrates a context term for each vertex by integrating information from all other vertices. This approach naturally incorporates long-range dependencies among joints in the context information and simplifies the network by removing the need for multiple stacked layers to enlarge receptive field.

log.reference: The authors propose a context aware graph convolutional network (CA-GCN). The paper introduces a novel multisensory interaction model called Synch-Graph that is inspired by neural synchrony in audiovisual multisensory integration in the brain. It utilizes spiking neural networks (SNN) and explores Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) for representing and learning neural synchrony patterns for emotion recognition.

The authors propose a new framework, DArtNet, which incorporates information from dynamic knowledge graphs to boost the accuracy of time series prediction, leverages a static embedding for each node in the graph and a dynamic embedding based on the time series, captures neighborhood information with relation-specific means and uses an RNN to encode historical information.

The authors propose the Dual Adversarial Graph Neural Networks (DAGNN) which is composed of dual generative adversarial networks and multi-hop graph neural networks, which can learn modality-invariant and discriminative common representations for cross-modal retrieval.

A Multi-scale Structure-aware Community value prediction network (MSC) is developed, which jointly models the structural information of different scales to predict the value of communities. This includes a Masked Edge Learning Graph Convolutional Network (MEL-GCN), a Pair-wise Community Pooling (PCPool) module, and a Multi-aggregator Framework (MAF).

target: The study proposes the design and creation of a machine-learning-based system, ScannerScope, that aims to detect web vulnerability scanners using fingerprinting techniques. ScannerScope works like a transparent reverse proxy injecting fingerprinting modules without the knowledge of protected web applications.
prediction: The authors propose a new BIQA method with hierarchical feature degradation (HFD), considering degradations on both low and high level features for quality assessment. An orientation selectivity (OS) based local visual structure is designed for low-level visual content extraction, and the deep semantics is extracted with the residual network for high-level visual content representation.

log.reference: The authors propose a new BIQA method with hierarchical feature degradation (HFD), considering degradations on both low and high level features for quality assessment. An orientation selectivity (OS) based local visual structure is designed for low-level visual content extraction, and the deep semantics is extracted with the residual network for high-level visual content representation.

The paper proposes a sparse representation-based classifier for assessing video quality which does not require a reference. This involves calculating the natural scene statistics (NSS) based spatial features of each frame and learning a dictionary from NSS features of correct frames, allowing for classification of frames as correct or distorted based on error score.

The authors propose to build a large subjective omnidirectional image quality database, considering key influential elements such as non-uniform distortion, viewing condition, and viewing behavior. They also propose training a convolutional neural network for blind omnidirectional image quality assessment, incorporating user viewing conditions and a two-part model involving a feature extraction module and a perceptual quality prediction module.

A new algorithm for BIQA is proposed based on the sparse representation of natural scene statistics (NSS) features. This is done through extracting NSS features in the wavelet domain, representing features via sparse coding, and then weighting differential mean opinion scores by the sparse coding coefficients to obtain the final visual quality values.

The authors propose an efficient approach for image retrieval from millions of images based on user-drawn sketches, which handles translation, scale, rotation, and small deformations. Database images are preprocessed to extract sequences of contour segments or 'chains' encapsulating shape information.

target: The authors propose SG-CQG, a two-stage CQG framework. It uses a semantic graph to select a sentence as the rationale and extract the answer span from it for the what-to-ask stage, and for the how-to-ask stage, it uses a classifier with explicit control signals to determine the target answer type of the question.
prediction: The authors propose a new task called Affordance-centric Question-driven Task Completion for AI assistant which should learn from instructional videos to provide step-by-step guidance in the user's view. A new dataset called 'AssistQ' and a model 'Question-to-Actions (Q2A)' are also introduced to address this new task.

log.reference: The authors propose a new task called Affordance-centric Question-driven Task Completion for AI assistant which should learn from instructional videos to provide step-by-step guidance in the user's view. A new dataset called 'AssistQ' and a model 'Question-to-Actions (Q2A)' are also introduced to address this new task.

The authors propose the Spoken Conversational Question Answering task (SCQA), placing an emphasis on modeling complex dialogue flows from audio recordings, and exploring options for providing additional context from multiple modalities. For this task, they propose a unified data distillation approach, DDNet, that ingests cross-modal information. They also suggest a novel mechanism, Dual Attention, for better alignment of audio and text.

The authors propose the problem of unsupervised multi-hop QA and introduce MQA-QG, an unsupervised question answering framework that generates human-like multi-hop training pairs from both homogeneous and heterogeneous data sources.

A new neural-symbolic QA approach is proposed, integrating natural logic reasoning with deep learning architectures to develop effective, explainable question answering models. Hypotheses and premises are represented using Hyperbolic space, as opposed to the conventional Euclidean space, to acquire more precise representations.

This paper presents TA-student VQA, a self-questioning model with multi-agent training that introduces question-generating mechanisms and collaborative learning questions between question-answering agents to overcome limitations in content diversity and question format.

target: This paper introduces the concept of distillation influence to gauge the impact of each training sample's distillation on the student model's generalization ability, and proposes Learning Good Teacher Matters (LGTM), a training technique incorporating the distillation influence into the teacher's learning process.
prediction: The authors propose a novel KD technique for ranking problems, called Ranking Distillation (RD). In this approach, a smaller student model learns to rank items from both the training data and the guidance of a larger teacher model.

log.reference: The authors propose a novel KD technique for ranking problems, called Ranking Distillation (RD). In this approach, a smaller student model learns to rank items from both the training data and the guidance of a larger teacher model.

This paper proposes dynamic knowledge distillation, a new method that allows the student model to adjust the learning procedure based on its competency, thereby improving student performance and learning efficiency.

This paper introduces a novel alternating knowledge distillation approach for CPL. The approach exploits both content- and graph-based models to handle cases when some concepts are not discovered during training.
This work introduces a novel framework, 'prune, then distill', that first prunes the teacher model to make it more transferrable, then distills this knowledge to the student model.

The authors identify a problem they call 'imbalanced training', wherein final models pay more attention to recently exposed samples than earlier ones during static training. To address this, they propose a concept called Complementary Online Knowledge Distillation (COKD) that uses dynamically updated teacher models to provide complementary knowledge to the student model.

target: The authors developed a large-scale Chinese movie benchmark named Movie101 which asks models to generate role-aware narration paragraphs for complete movie clips without dialogue. They also propose a new metric, Movie Narration Score (MNScore), for movie narrating evaluation, which better correlates with human evaluation.
prediction: The authors suggest that discarding FP from all LM histories can improve performance and that most FP indicate hesitations rather than restarts.

log.reference: The authors suggest that discarding FP from all LM histories can improve performance and that most FP indicate hesitations rather than restarts.

This study proposes Prompts Augmented by Retrieval Crosslingually (PARC), a pipeline designed to augment the context with semantically similar sentences retrieved from a high-resource language (HRL) as prompts for improving zero-shot performance on LRLs.

The authors propose PromptSource, a system for creating, sharing, and using natural language prompts which also features a templating language for defining data-linked prompts, an output observation interface for prompt development, and a set of guidelines for contributing new prompts.

The authors propose a new method for NER which includes designing multiple prompt schemas to enhance label semantics and a novel architecture that effectively combines these prompt-based representations.

This paper introduces a novel paradigm for program semantics learning which suggests that the model should learn from the fundamental operations in operational semantics and the information of environment transition, which is crucial for program understanding. Furthermore, the authors present OSCAR, a hierarchical Transformer-based pre-training model to facilitate the understanding of programs.

target: The authors propose a new LID model which they train on a curated dataset of monolingual data, and present a thorough analysis of its performance in comparison to other existing models.

The authors explore the systematic comparison of MLM with alternative objectives that produce inputs resembling real (full) sentences, through reordering and replacing words based on their context.

The authors propose an approach to automatically generate test cases using one language model (LM) to identify potentially harmful behaviour in another target LM, a concept referred to as "red teaming".

The authors introduced the MASSIVE dataset, a Multilingual Amazon Slu resource package for Slot-filling, Intent classification, and Virtual assistant Evaluation, that contains 1M parallel, labeled virtual assistant utterances spanning 51 languages, 18 domains, 60 intents, and 55 slots.

This study uncovers a challenge that established models such as the Transformer almost completely fail at generalizing inflection patterns when trained on a limited number of lemmata and asked to inflect previously unseen lemmata under "wug test"-like circumstances.

target: The authors propose a more balanced adversarial model, where the adversary consists of two separated algorithms: the sampler that chooses the distribution and provides the samples, and the analyst who chooses the adaptive queries without prior knowledge of the underlying distribution.

The paper addresses these issues by proposing mixup regularized adversarial training (MRAT), which can utilize multiple adversarial examples to increase a model's intrinsic robustness, without impairing its performance on normal data.

The authors propose a novel approach of friendly adversarial training (FAT) that employs least adversarial (friendly adversarial) data that is confidently misclassified, instead of most adversarial data which maximize the loss.

The authors propose a model-agnostic method that generates adversarially sampled data based on the few support samples, and fine-tunes the embedding space of a base classifier in a manner that increases the classification margins of these adversarial samples, making the classifier more robust.

The authors point out that standard adversarial training methods that focus on fickle adversarial examples can make a model more vulnerable to obstinate adversarial examples. Toward this, they propose Balanced Adversarial Training, incorporating contrastive learning to increase robustness against both types of adversarial examples.

target: This paper puts into question the importance of such explanations, finding that corrupted explanations can still result in competitive or superior performance. It is proposed that explanations' main effect is the provision of extra context space, rather than their inductive biases.
prediction: The authors study the problem of correcting assertions in KBs and propose a general correction framework that combines lexical matching, semantic embedding, soft constraint mining and semantic consistency checking.

log.reference: The authors study the problem of correcting assertions in KBs and propose a general correction framework that combines lexical matching, semantic embedding, soft constraint mining and semantic consistency checking.

The paper presents a theory on how factors such as context, current knowledge, and specific information needs affect the evaluation of explanations. It proposes the need to distinguish between good and bad explanations.

The authors introduce a model of active learners, accompanied by a new, efficient teaching algorithm that respects the capability of human learners to choose whether to review a historical example or receive a new example, based on their belief about their learning state.
The paper suggests a new alternative for domain-independent data analysis, inferred from a close examination of empirical results from a scientific experiment.
The authors present a novel, black-box algorithm for executing explanations based on a principled approach from causal theory in a tool called DeepCover.

target: The paper introduces a new large-scale Korean dataset named Sensitive Questions and Acceptable Response (SQuARe), consisting of 49k sensitive questions accompanied by 42k acceptable and 46k non-acceptable responses. This dataset aims to support safer models in sensitive discussions.

The authors propose an approach for open QA that deals with both tabular and textual data. They also introduce a dataset, Open Table-Text Question Answering (OTT-QA), designed specifically to evaluate this approach.

The authors present a new Question-Answering dataset called StepGame designed for robust, multi-step spatial reasoning in texts and a Tensor-Product based Memory-Augmented Neural Network (TP-MANN) specialized for these spatial reasoning tasks.

The authors introduce a new dataset, HiTab, to study question answering (QA) and natural language generation (NLG) over hierarchical tables. The data for HiTab is collected from various statistical reports and Wikipedia pages and it provides fine-grained annotations of quantity and entity alignment to reveal complex numerical reasoning in analysis.

target: The authors make use of general-purpose language models, trained on large amounts of diverse data, to solve tasks without task-specific training, with a focus on the ChatGPT research preview for zero-shot DST.

The authors propose AEDA (An Easier Data Augmentation), a new approach that involves only random insertion of punctuation marks into the original text, which is easier to implement than EDA and keeps the original order of words, thus preserving all input information.

The authors investigate how pre-trained language models can be utilized to generate entire conversations given only a summary of a conversation as the input and explore three approaches to generate these summary grounded conversations.

The authors propose an ensemble setup composed of GPT-2 and ground-truth graphs from one of seven different formalisms, aiming to determine whether the incorporation of graph information can enhance perplexity and other metrics, thereby improving language modelling.

The authors introduce a novel natural language generator based on the sequence-to-sequence model. This approach can produce both natural language strings and deep syntax dependency trees from input dialogue acts, thereby creating a direct comparison between the traditional two-step generation approach and a joint, one-step approach.

target: The authors propose scalable methods, namely, fairness-based participant sampling (FPS) and fairness as context (FAC), that use node representations learned from diffusion cascades rather than social connectivity for achieving influence maximization with fairness on large networks.
prediction: The authors initiate the exploration of control actions in fair division problems, with the specific case study of adding or deleting a small number of items to improve fairness.

log.reference: The authors initiate the exploration of control actions in fair division problems, with the specific case study of adding or deleting a small number of items to improve fairness.

The paper proposes studying the dynamics of population qualification and algorithmic decisions within the context of a partially observed Markov decision problem, so as to analyze the long-term impact of static fairness constraints on group well-being.

The authors propose extending equalized odds to cardinality-constrained fair classification, drawing concepts from fair division problems that relate different allocation instances to prevent paradoxes.

The paper proposes the use of randomized policies for selecting an optimal solution in KEPs, with the goal of promoting patients' equal opportunity to receive a transplant, as a way to achieve individual fairness.
The study aims to understand the contribution of representation to learning with the goal of autonomizing the process of representation selection and design in machine learning systems.

target: The paper suggests a method to examine the unwanted dependencies learned by abusive language classifiers by assessing their accuracy on a challenge set across all decision thresholds. It introduces concept-based explanation metrics to assess the influence of a concept on labels which allows comparison of classifiers in terms of the degree of false global sufficiency they have learned.
prediction: The authors present a general framework for neural novelty detection involving a multivariate extension of the univariate quantile function. Their framework potentially descends from and develops many classical and recent novelty detection algorithms.

The study questions and analyzes the effectiveness of these concept removal methods. The authors argue that these methods, due to their reliance on a probing classifier as a proxy for the concept, are unable to remove the concepts entirely, and may even destroy all task-relevant features.
The paper proposes a method of detecting these errors while also presenting techniques for improving the accuracy of error detection with limited training data.

The authors propose a way of improving this bias-accuracy tradeoff by using a biased discriminator in a feature masking approach based on the discriminator's gradients. This process emphasizes the use of unbiased features and de-emphasizes potentially biased ones during classification.

target: The authors implemented methods to improve review quality, create a clearer workflow for area chairs, improve paper-reviewer matching for a variety of NLP work, and boost incentives for all participants involved in the peer review process at the ACL'23 conference.
prediction: The authors present AnnoMarket, an open cloud-based platform which enables researchers to handle language processing components and resources with ease, following the data-as-a-service and software-as-a-service paradigms.

log.reference: The authors present AnnoMarket, an open cloud-based platform which enables researchers to handle language processing components and resources with ease, following the data-as-a-service and software-as-a-service paradigms.

The authors aim to identify suitable methodologies for evaluating automatic captioning tools for DHH users at different literacy levels. They propose several probes including multiple-choice comprehension-question accuracy or response time, scalar-questions about user estimation of ASR errors or their impact, and users' numerical estimation of accuracy.
The authors conduct a thorough examination of this new reading comprehension task to understand the depth of language understanding necessary to perform well on this task.

This paper proposes the design and development of AutoSAS, an automated system for Short Answer Scoring (SAS), which uses features like lexical diversity, Word2Vec, prompt, and content overlap to grade responses to a particular question based on provided graded samples.

The authors present WikiReading, a novel large-scale natural language understanding task, and a publicly available dataset with 18 million instances, wherein the task is to predict textual values from Wikidata by reading the text of corresponding Wikipedia articles.

target: The authors leverage pretrained models that have been exposed to large-scale audio and text data. They introduce several stages of additional pretraining and fine-tuning to adapt the system for the downstream speech translation task, supplemented with techniques such as data augmentation, domain tagging, knowledge distillation, and model ensemble.
prediction: The authors propose to solve ATSC with natural language prompts, which enables the task to be performed under zero-shot cases and improves performance in supervised settings, particularly for few-shot cases. The authors propose an unsupervised, syntactically controlled paraphrase generation model, the AMR-enhanced Paraphrase Generator (AMRPG), which leverages Abstract Meaning Representations (AMR) to improve the quality of generated paraphrases.

The authors propose conditional language-specific routing (CLSR), which uses hard binary gates conditioned on token representations to dynamically select between LS or shared paths, and can schedule LS capacity across sub-layers in MNMT based on translation signals and budget constraints.

The authors propose a multi-task learning approach using an AT model as an auxiliary task to improve NAT performance. This is based on their hypothesis that AT and NAT encoders capture different linguistic properties and representations of source sentences.

The authors introduce a novel decoding approach, based on the method of auxiliary coordinates, which introduces discrete variables for output tokens and auxiliary continuous variables representing the states of the underneath ARM. This approach addresses the shortcomings of error propagation and myopic decisions in existing methods.

target: This paper provides an overview of complex reasoning tasks where standard pretrained language models fail then reviews recent promising methods for tackling these tasks, which explicitly consider problem structures. These methods include: knowledge-augmented method, few-shot prompting methods, neuro-symbolic methods, and rationale-based methods.
prediction: This paper aims at understanding and disentangling interactions between different continual learning methods and PLMs to improve continual learning performance.

log.reference: This paper aims at understanding and disentangling interactions between different continual learning methods and PLMs to improve continual learning performance.

The authors propose Knowledge Infused Decoding (KID), a novel decoding algorithm for generative LMs, designed to dynamically infuse external knowledge into each step of the LM decoding. This method maintains a local knowledge memory based on the current context, interacts with a dynamically created external knowledge trie, and continuously updates the local memory as a knowledge-aware constraint to guide decoding.

The authors propose a method of augmenting the training data with natural language advice from a human to address this issue. This advice can include guidance on what actions to take and where to focus attention.

This paper introduces DKPLM, a novel KEPLM that decomposes the knowledge injection process across the pre-training, fine-tuning, and inference stages to enhance semantic understanding and speed up inference. The model targets knowledge-aware long-tail entities for knowledge injection and replaces the embeddings of these entities with 'pseudo token representations' formed by relevant knowledge triples.
The authors hypothesize that models like OpenAI Codex, which are pre-trained on code, would prove more adept at semantic parsing due to their understanding of executable semantics.

target: The authors introduce a benchmark dataset named CLUB (Chemical Language Understanding Benchmark), one of the first chemical language understanding benchmark datasets consisting of tasks for both patent and literature articles provided by an industrial organization.
prediction: A new teacher-student learning method is proposed to address these limitations in cross-lingual NER. Here, NER models from source languages are used as 'teachers' to train a 'student' model on unlabeled data in the target language.

log.reference: A new teacher-student learning method is proposed to address these limitations in cross-lingual NER. Here, NER models from source languages are used as 'teachers' to train a 'student' model on unlabeled data in the target language.

The paper presents a new approach called contextual quantization of token embeddings. This decouples document-specific and document-independent ranking contributions during codebook-based compression, which in turn, allows effective online decompression and embedding composition for better search relevance.

The authors aim to examine the robustness of these models' ability to deploy relevant context information in the presence of distracting content by presenting models with cloze tasks requiring critical context information, and introducing distracting content.

The authors introduce a new model known as hierarchical latent word language model (h-LWLM), which generalizes standard LWLMs by implementing a hierarchical structure for multiple latent variable spaces to account for novel linguistic phenomena.

The authors propose an improvement to the multitask ST model by using word embedding as an intermediate. They argue it's more crucial that the output of the recognition decoder has the correct semantics than its accuracy.

target: SEScore2, a self-supervised approach for training a model-based metric for text generation evaluation, is proposed. The key concept is to synthesize realistic model mistakes by perturbing sentences retrieved from a corpus.
prediction: The authors introduce SESCORE, a model-based metric for NLG that uses a novel, iterative error synthesis and severity scoring pipeline, and achieves high correlation with human judgments without requiring human annotation.

log.reference: The authors introduce SESCORE, a model-based metric for NLG that uses a novel, iterative error synthesis and severity scoring pipeline, and achieves high correlation with human judgments without requiring human annotation.
This study introduces the use of double embeddings, where the embeddings are trained on both the forward and backward direction of the input sequence, to enhance sequence-to-sequence systems.
This paper studies the combined use of several weakly supervised techniques to enhance natural language understanding (NLU) accuracy in low-resource environments.
The authors investigate the impact of fine-tuning on the capacity of contextualized embeddings to capture phrase meaning information beyond lexical content.

SimLM (Similarity matching with Language Model pre-training) is introduced as a simple, effective pre-training method for dense passage retrieval. It uses a bottleneck architecture to compress passage information into a dense vector through self-supervised pre-training, inspired by the replaced language modeling objective of ELECTRA.

target: Cornet is introduced, a system that automatically learns conditional formatting rules from user examples, efficiently eliminating the need for manual rule writing.
prediction: The authors designed and implemented Termino, a comprehensive terminological resource for text processing that can store terminological information in a flexible, extensible relational database and execute term lookups using finite-state machines compiled from this database.

log.reference: The authors designed and implemented Termino, a comprehensive terminological resource for text processing that can store terminological information in a flexible, extensible relational database and execute term lookups using finite-state machines compiled from this database.

The paper proposes a methodology to reuse semantic structures while switching between several representation languages. In the process, the authors present a concept of semantic patterns to communicate knowledge at a certain level of representation.

The paper proposes an innovative solution that uses a combination of lexical approaches and language games to reduce the complexity of the semantic problem by shifting from the ontology level to the simpler lexicon level and avoids the use of a centralized third party mediator.

The authors evaluate the feasibility of integrating an available discourse analyser called HILDA for a question generation system called CODA and introduce an approach for extracting a discourse corpus from the CODA parallel corpus.

The authors propose a framework that presents standards for annotating information status and provides guidelines for annotating information structure, i.e., theme/rheme and background/kontrast, in the Switchboard corpus.
